posts.com:
We encourage you to have a look around the catalog first to see what we’re all about before posting your first thread. Topics typically posted here include:
>Outdoor recreational activities (Hiking, trail running, bushwhacking, camping, spelunking, geocaching, orienteering, expeditions, urban exploration, backpacking, etc.)
>Gardening, farming and related activities
>Hunting and fishing, and other activities involving the stalking or taking of game (including bird-watching)
>Outdoor survival, bushcraft, foraging, self-sustenance in nature, train-hopping, hoboism, etc.
>Outdoor destinations and exploration (specific trails, parks, regions, etc.)
>Water-related activities (boats, diving, etc.)
>Outdoor philosophy (conservation, Leave No Trace, protectionism, etc.)
>Outdoor building and living (cabins, huts, treehouses, etc.)
>Outdoor social activities and organizations (meet-ups, Scouts, NOLS, etc.)
>Gear related to any of the above topics

Most topics related to the outdoors are fine. Write properly, behave politely, encourage a respectful community, and most importantly, GO OUTSIDE!!

How much resistance should be in the pipe when I breathe in?
I'm new, not sure if I packed it too loose. But I feel I have to take quick shallow breaths as there is no resistance for me to suck like a straw. By the time I suck in I am out of breath.
Like I know I dont inhale, but when I put my lips on the pipe, and draw I can't pull enough air into my mouth because there's TOO MUCH air flow it feels.
Maybe Im just not used to it. But without any tobacco in the bowl it feels the same. Just way too much air.

Like with a straw you can suck air if nothing is on the other end, but when you put liquid through it it creates a bit of pressure and you can then actually suck it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519009
That's what tamping is for. There should be enough resistance that it feels a little like sucking through a straw. You definitely packed it way too loose.

Packing a bowl is like parallel parking a car--there are plenty of different techniques and sets of steps people will tell you, but they're all crutches for newbies and once you get experience you'll end up just doing it by feel. But one way you can try is to fill the pipe, then crush it down with your thumb till the bowl is half full. Top it off, and crush it down again until the bowl is 3/4 full. Then top it off again, light and enjoy. Remember to tamp as you smoke, any time it's pulling in too much air you need to tamp again.

>>2519009
It mostly has to do with packing the pipe which is something that comes with experience.

Best way to explain how to pack a pipe is this.
You pack a pipe 3 times, and each time you treat it like a handshake
The first pinch you pack down firmly, think of shaking hands with another man.
The second pinch you pack down lightly, like hsaking hands with a woman
The third pinch you pack down gently like shaking the hand of a child.

It comes with practice.

posts.com:
>>2519681
Depends. If it's too wet, you'll know it. There will be nasty liquid coming out the end of the pipe stem. It's probably just too hot.

Tobacco tastes the best when it's burning cooler, almost on the verge of going out. You're probably getting tongue bite from smoking it too hot and fast.

Part of your problem may be your tobacco, or your pipe. If your tobacco's too dry, it will burn super hot but burn out quickly and you won't be able to get a good coal without tongue bite. If it's too wet, steam and gross liquid. There's a sweet spot of perfectly moist you need to learn to recognize. Also, are you using a shit pipe? If you're broke use a Missouri Meerschaum corncob. Shit pipe geometry can cause these problems, I prefer a narrow and deep bowl.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520793
It'll do the job, but there is no carb like you're used to if you smoke a bowl. It's not optimized for weed and you'll probably have a better smoking experience using dedicated weed smoking pieces.

You can mix it with tobacco if you like--do that if you enjoy smoking spliffs--but don't use pipe tobacco. Weed is meant to inhale, pipe tobacco is meant to puff. Use RYO cigarette tobacco instead.

And please for the love of fuck don't smoke weed out of a nice pipe you regularly use for tobacco. Use a different pipe. Tobacco pipes build character from regular usage--kind of like the seasoning on a cast iron pan--and smoking anything else from the pipe can fuck that all up.

posts.com:
>>2519001
Did you plant and harvest that tobacco yourself? Any tips on growing and preparing?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521337
Plant after the last frost. Once it germinates, it should be pretty carefree until harvest time. If it starts to flower, either put a bag over the seeds if you want to plant them next year, or clip off the flowers if you want more leaves.

To harvest, start at the bottom of the plant and work your way up, cutting off the leaves one at a time when they reach full size.
To cure, tie the leaves together in bunches and hang them up in a warm space out of direct sunlight to dry until they turn completely brown.
To prep, cut the main ribs out of the leaves and then cut them into thinnish slices.
None of this is hard, it just takes time.

>>2522317
>>2522486
I’ve found a method that works for me with straight Virginia flakes.
>dry for about 20 minutes
>rub out completely and finely
>dry rubbed out flake for about 15 more minutes
>gravity fill pipe
>gently push down to the halfway point of the bowl
>gravity fill again
>use the meaty part of your thumb to move any hanging tobacco into the bowl without pushing down on the tobacco that already in the bowl
>light
>very gently even out the tobacco
>light again
>again, gently tamp the tobacco
>do the final light
>enjoy, and always try a relight first without tamping; only tamp if the tobacco can absolutely no longer catch the flame
Straight Virginia flakes are probably the hardest type of tobacco to prepare and smoke correctly. Flakes tend to hold onto moisture extremely well. Even if they feel dry to the touch, they’re probably still way more moist than any other ribbon cut tobacco you own. The drying time is necessary before packing. Virginia flakes also expand quite a lot once they get hot, meaning a loose pack is essential. If you pack it using the three pack method like a ribbon cut, it may be fine before you light it, but as soon as it warms up it’s going to expand so much that no oxygen will be able to reach the tobacco, making the ember go out extremely quickly. And because it expands, tamping regularly will compact the tobacco even more, which will make it unsmokable, so you’ll always want to go for a relight first when smoking a flake, and only tamp when absolutely necessary. Kinda a lot of info, but it’ll become second nature once you get the hang of it.

>>2524891
this probably isn't what you were saying, but i'll take the chance to discuss a technique i've been working on recently. i find that searching the internet for something like "pipe smoking technique" gives basically 0 results that are worth a damn. it's mostly boomers complaining about people inhaling or young people whining about not enjoying this hobby. here is what i've been working on, hopefully it helps newer folks.

first off, it's FINE to have to relight. not abnormal at all, especially on a new pipe, or if your filter is a little old, or if you're smoking just-opened leaf (or highly aromatic) as the moisture content will be higher inherently.
second, it's actually a good idea to proactively tamp and re-light after the first minute or two. this helps spread the embers around some and keep the bowl evenly lit.
goals of this technique:
>keep a constant light drag on the bowl at nearly all times
>breathe normally, or even meditatively
>NEVER inhale (unless that's your thing, in which case ignore this)

ok so here are my thoughts:
>practice dragging through the bowl without using your lungs or diaphragm at all
>if you're a band nerd, a word you might have heard was embouchure, which is french for "doing shit with your mouth / lips"
>basically, you're going to seal your mouth up and pull a slight vacuum using your facial muscles NOT your lungs
>you probably already do this, but it's something specifically to practice modulating to get a slow drag without opening your throat to your mouth
>now practice breathing while doing that cheek-drag technique
>slow everything down to a crawl, so that you're breathing slow and dragging soft enough to just keep the ember lit
i shoot for 4 deep breaths per drag
this gives the smoke a ton of time in your mouth to absorb, it keeps the flame very healthily lit, and makes the entire experience more meditative, which is one reason i smoke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525274
When you breathe through your nose, the airway in your throat closes. It’s physically impossible to breathe through your nose and mouth at the exact same time. Try attempting it. It’s what prevents you from getting a shit ton of liquid or food in your lungs when you’re breathing through your nose while eating or drinking. As long as all the smoke is out of your mouth the next time you breathe through your mouth, you won’t inhale anything at all. Practice with a straw if you like. Get a straw, some water, and practice the breath method that way if you’re afraid about inhaling. You’ll see that no water is getting into your lungs (unless you choke on water all the time like my dumb ass), which means smoke won’t be getting in there either. Then when you’re ready, you can try it with an actual pipe. I had the same concern since I started smoking cigars before a pipe, and because the cigar gives off so much smoke, it’s a lot harder to keep a cigar in your mouth without choking. The pipe gives off wisps of smoke, making it much easier to just hold it in your mouth. My only problem with the breath method is that it makes me drool a lot sometimes.

Alrighty then I'll be impatient.

[Red] Elm tends to have grain which doesn't run straight, but it turns -- usually clockwise or counter-clockwise -- as the tree grows, often a different direction every season (like ... it's still basically vertical along the trunk, just sort of twisted around the tree as it goes).

It might have some pretty grain thanks to this, once you oil and wax it.

But also be aware that even as a hardwood, elm tends to be sappy. That alone is enough to discourage people from using it for firewood, especially for a cooking fire. So if you think a lot of sap (say, as with a pine pipe) might negatively affect your smoke too much, perhaps it's not your best option to use elm. But as always, your mileage may vary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Noob here

Tips for lighting/expectations for keeping pipe lit?
How do I keep from slobbering on my pipe?
Is it OK to relite multiple times if I have to set the pipe down?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527164
For the initial light, you’re just going to try to char the top layer of tobacco in a circular motion until it stops expanding. Once you’re done charring it, tamp it so it’s even, then relight again in a circular motion. The first several puffs should be kinda quick and rapid to get the ember going, but after that you’ll wanna slow it down. Relighting is fine. It’s part of smoking your pipe. Sometimes you might only relight once. Sometimes you’ll relight seven times. Hell, just this morning I relit a half smoked pipe that I couldn’t finish last night because it was too cold outside.

>>2527164
>keeping pipe lit
Smoke more. You can learn all the techniques in the world but ultimately you have to do it by feel. Tamp it as needed to keep your draw feeling "right". When the draw gets too easy and you're sucking in air, tamp. That should keep your coal going and minimize re-lighting, but it's normal to have to re-light a couple times through smoking especially depending on your tobacco and your bowl geometry.
>saliva on pipe
You're not Popeye. Don't try to clench the pipe the entire time. If saliva is becoming an issue just hold the pipe in your hand. You'll get the hang of clenching with more experience but I've been smoking for a couple years and I still get the saliva issue if I try to clench too long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529827
Sure if you are full blown moron maybe stick with AAs. If you can't possibly think ahead enough to bring a spare battery sure.

But ultimately what matters is the amount of power stored in the battery and how it can deliver it. A premium AA delivers 1.5v and stores about 2200 milliamphours. An 18650, for example. delivers 3.7v and stores 3500 milliamphours.

This means 1 18650 has the energy of a bit more than 3 AAs. If you care about high drain applications like super bright ass lights a AA maxes out at 2 amps while the best 18650s will do 35 amps.

So you can get a whole pile more light (more than 3x) from a full 18650 than you can a AA. If you do use that much light in a single trip they can all be recharged, some even have built in USB ports so you don't need a separate charger. Of course you can also get lights with built in chargers, either USB ports or sealed magnetic contacts.

And this is just 18650s. The difference against 26650s are even bigger.

Only a fucking moron would think being able to buy a AA in a gas station is a meaningful advantage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
actually sometimes acrylic or nylon are added on purpose to make the garment less stretchy.
my thoughts on blends:
if its done as an intentional design decision, up to +0.5 tier
if its done to cut costs, up to -0.5 tier
and those blends where its like 30%/30%/30%/10% of various animal fibers, no idea how to score those, really depends.

if anyone's ever used camel's hair let me know where i should slot it. i forgot to include that one.
if anyone's used all the various sheep/lamb's wools out there i'd like to hear how you rank them too.
i also think i should bump cotton up to niche tier. it gets a bad rap and it partially deserves it, but it has its niche: pretty much every other fiber with high durability has gross hand feeling, & its one of the only durable fibers that doesn't melt easy. even with all the choices i have in my gear closet: i often reach for a cotton flannel when i'm day hiking in the mountains in the fall on a good weather forecast. or if i'm doing anything high abrasion on my gear like swinging an axe or running a chainsaw all day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2518208

>Cotton base layer

Death sentence. Cotton absorbs moisturize which results in the loss of any thermal properties. All of your sweat will adhere to your skin as dampness and make you colder. This can be lethal if all that dampness starts to freeze. Wool fibers also absorb sweat but they breathe better and keep their thermal properties when damp.

To quote the Norwegian Armed Forces winter clothing literature:

>On the negative side, cotton is a fibre that easily absorbs moisture and requires
impregnation in order to withstand the damp. Cotton absorbs and accumulates
moisture, which results in its insulating properties being lost even with a small
degree of damp. When a cotton garment is wet it becomes heavy and takes a
relatively long time to dry.

Merino is so popular because the fibers are smooth enough to be comfortable in itch-prone areas. I've heard alpaca wool has ever smoother fibers but have no experience with it and I don't think it's common.

So try merino wool as your directly-against-the-skin base layer. If that's still itchy, then wear synthetic. Anything but cotton.

I had an extra al paca scarf in my 50lb backpack that I got close to using but didnt need. Had wool socks and hiking boots on, and felt great. >>2529860
some people don't have a choice m8, although you're right that it helps to buy better wool.

If ya'll want a protip, if you find that you have skin sensitivity plus sensitivity to light/sound (e.g. you feel excessively touchy and uncomfortable in supermarkets or music stores that tend to be bright and noisy), it might be neurological. Can't remember what it's called, but your brain is getting overloaded with hyper-stimulus from normal stimuli. It's related to ADHD/OCD/the rest of it and exists on a spectrum, ie. you can be very hyper-sensitive or you can be mildly hyper-sensitive under certain conditions.

The bad thing is you can't cure it. The good thing is you can easily treat the primary symptom (everything feels so itchy/bright/noisy/etc, but so much more than "makes sense" when you think about the lights or the sounds in isolation, and yet it's impossible to ignore): When you get up in the morning, gently rub your body all over with something mildly abrasive like a sponge or a soft brush and use a medium or stiff brush on your hair. Your nails will work but it helps to use a tool of some kind. You'll eventually feel oddly relaxed, like you got out of the bath. Your hyper-stimulus symptoms will be lessened for the rest of the day. Just don't overdo it, because you can go too far and irritate the skin/other obvious outcomes.

This tip does not help people who do not have hyper-sensitivity issues. If you're just a wimp then it cannot help. The cure for being a wimp is to progressively toughen up by increasing challenges, just like with building strength or endurance. Your mind is a muscle and can be trained and manipulated like any other part of the body. It might help to know that the majority of physiological changes (e.g. RBC count, cold sensitivity, depressant dependency, etc) will noticeably improve after 2-4 weeks of training. Stick out any training routine for one month before saying "what I'm doing doesn't seem to work."

posts.name: anon
posts.sub: The best agrochemicals to use on a small and large scale
posts.com:
In this thread I want to share the best agrichemicals that I use during my crops, they are all recommended by an agricultural engineer with a lot of experience. All agrichemicals fall into the organic category, but are still extremely effective.

deltamethrin (common trade name decis 10 from bayer)
It is extremely cheap, and effective, it kills all aphids, but it has a short effect of maximum 3 or 4 days, so it is recommended to apply it once a week, or once every two weeks. To apply it, you only have to use an atomizer or a backpack. It is always good to apply it as a preventative, and more or less you have to apply about 6% of the product in the water.
>copper oxychloride
It is a very powerful fungicide, which kills all fungi, preventing them from reproducing. It is good that when you prepare the soil you mix it with this to prevent fungus in the roots. You also have to spray it on the stem and leaves with a sprayer, the amounts don't really matter, but don't put too little either. They sell this product already prepared, but it sucks, it has to be powdered.
>diatomaceous earth
This is undoubtedly the best of all, since you have multiple uses, both for fertilizing, for killing ants (these are really difficult to kill), killing worms, mites, among others, it also serves as a fungicide for your ph. But they have to be careful not to apply it on the flowers as it can kill the bees.
>rice
This is not an agrochemical, and it does not kill anyone, but when the ants take it to their colony, they leave it stored and the rice starch generates a fungus that they end up eating, that fungus ends up killing them.

posts.name: anon
posts.com:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deltamethrin
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dicopper_chloride_trihydroxide
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diatomaceous_earth
Remember that if you are going to use them, always apply beforehand as a preventative. These agrochemicals literally kill everything but prevention is better than cure.
They are cheap, but many times they sell it in small bags as novelty inventions or something like that and they end up charging you 1000 times more than it is worth. I am from Argentina and I paid 2 usd for a kilo of pure diatom, surely it is worth much more there, but make sure by the color that it is pure, and that it is not mixed.

posts.name: anon
posts.com: I use diatomaceous earth for the fungus on my feet, and for the cockroaches in my house, and the truth is that it is very safe, so sure that if it is 100% pure you can put it in your mouth and nothing happens. In fact, diatoms are often used to deworm animals and even for human use in some foods.

Went rock climbing today for the first time in a while, have some questions.

1. The easiest auto belay route seems to be 5.6, is this normal?

2. I managed to do one 5.6, but the other 5.6 was too hard for me.

3. They have chalk air purifiers, but after an hour or two my throat started getting super irritated and I started coughing, and even water didn’t help. Is this normal/is there a way to prevent it?

4. Do people go rock climbing as beginners alone often? When I was trying to do the harder 5.6 and got stuck, I got kind of sad that I had no one to help me. There are also a lot of top rope routes that I can’t do since I have no partner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2496472

1. probably, grades start at 5.7 at my gym and go through 5.11's

2. well done, muscles used in climbing arent really used in our everyday life so it'll be hard to start but stick at it and you'll progress quickly I guarantee

3. not really? you shouldn't be creating huge chalk clouds when you chalk up just enough to coat your palms and fingers inside of your chalk bag. maybe try not to breath in chalk if you see it floating

4. people boulder alone often, trick is if you see someone alone to ask if they want to top rope, most people are happy enough. its worth trying to strike up conversation with people bouldering to then organize a roped climb on a later date.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503084
You’d be backclipped on the bolt they were lowering off. He TR’ed it, then at the bolt had to make the switch to lead. I tried to go through the scenario in my garage and came to the conclusion the leader unclipped, reclipped but there may have been a stuck gate he did not notice that did not close. However, rather than woulda-coulda-shoulda the guy, I’ll just say he crushed it and I’m glad it all worked out.

How would you re-do this scenario to be safer next time?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503108
To be clear: my understanding is that after your failed lead he was TR on his end of the rope, which was running through the QDs. So it was necessary for him to unclip each one as he passed.

The critical idea here is to never rely on a single bolt. When your partner reached the second-to-last draw, he should have clipped the belayer strand into the draw before unclipping his own strand and continuing on.

Swapping the rope in the last QD to avoid the backclip is a weird situation. I'm honestly not sure how to do that safely. I'll have to try it out on my own to see if there's a way to swap without unclipping...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503108
attach to the belay, swap lead and belay, put a quickdraw on the line if you're worried about swinging out and jump it over each clip, then lead as normal to the top.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2503108
>>2503134
Just pull the rope out and let the other guy lead normally?
unless the bolt distances are far between, its much better constantly risking a 5-10m fall then having the one bolt fail and having a 30m+ factor 2 fall... Depending on how youre belaying, this could actually kill you both.

Always leave biners. You'll be okay without, but when you pull the rope it will cut the webbing, or leave it very damaged for the next person. People have theorized that the two recent deaths in Tahquitz were due to a previous party rapping off the webbing and leaving it damaged.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2522449
Is there any particular kind of glove I should wear? Or will like normal winter gloves with good grip work?
Are there mid range priced boots that will fit crampons or do you need those alpine mountaineering boots?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2522560
Not the other anon, but get two pairs of gloves, good water resistant ones for the actual climbing which ideally are also tighter, so you can manipulate the screws and carabiners and warmer, cheaper ones for belaying and abseiling which will get more wear and tear. Potentially a backup superwarm pair in the backpack if your fingers start to shut down.
Also protip, keep the gloves youre not using under a few of your layers near your tits, so they keep warm.
As for crampons, ideally youll want fully automatic ones, so they dont slide off when youre kicking for footholds. That usually means full alpine boots that have that rubber edge for clipping crampons both in front and the back. It's doable in semi automatics, but kinda meh.
Definitely don't use walking crampons with flat front spikes.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525750
>free solo climbing
No rope, no harness, no gear. Exceptions can be made for a route with no walk off or easy way down and requires a tag line, harness and rap device brought along that is not used in the ascent.

>Free climbing
Gear, rope and belay is used, but the climbers body is the primary, if not the only allowed, means of ascent.

>aid climbing
The climbers entire gear system is used to aid in the ascent. Some free climbing may be employed between easy ground, but the gear is primarily used to achieve the ascent.

>solo free climbing
The climber uses the gear and system in a solo style, and free climbs the route using the gear as a back up in case of danger or as a backup. This requires the climber to do each pitch twice as free and aid on a fixed line and ascenders (unless they are absolutely insane).

>solo aid climbing
The tactics employed by the solo free climber, but the gear is the primary mode of ascent.

I think I covered most of it. Feel free to chime in autists.

Lots of caves do this. I’m by no means a sport climber nor am I good enough to hop on cave routes, but it’s probably a factor of a good clipping stance doesn’t have good rock quality to hold a bolt, and the spot with good rock quality doesn’t have a clipping stance, so to bring them together they give the draw the stendo and you keep on with a sendo. also, an extended draw might throw you down a bit further and make it near impossible to get back on route if you’re hangdogging. So now you have to lower off and relead the route if you biff it, which seems harder to me…. 70ft of overhung .13a before the tricky bolt that you keep falling at and can’t doink up to so you can practice that sequence…. Wew lad

TL;DR extendo draws don’t really matter at all lol it’s a non issue

From a mountain project post, the rescuer:

To my knowledge, that was the climber's first Free Solo, and I'm sure it will be his last. The poor guy was really shaken up, and the route was well below his ability. I'm glad we do not have another report of a climber's death or suffering from a severe injury. The climber was not alone on The Eye. He was with a friend who, from all other witness accounts, had peer pressured him into climbing the eye. I wanted to have a conversation with this person, but the stuck climber was shaken up, and I didn't want to make matters worse for him.

The friend that (likely) encouraged this free solo, if you are reading this, please realize Free Soloing should only be done for intrinsic reasons. As you said, free soloing is not for everyone, and I agree. We all need nudges to push ourselves in climbing but the risk we choose to take should be our own risk and not determined by others. I saw both of you on the rock from Intersection rock and we could tell something wasn't right. We walked over looking to climb The Eye since other routes were taken at Intersection Rock. Both of you had made little progress on the route and I assume your friend was apprehensive. Based on the conversations I heard you were encouraging your friend to summit but not watching out for his safety. In the future, please listen to your climbing partner and support them don't push them.

This is not meant to be an internet shame but just a tip to help support other climbers in a supportive/safer manner. I'm glad I was there to help and I will continue offering help if it doesn't put me or others at risk. Please note, others who were aware of the situation either walked away or said they would not have helped (Shame on those climbers! We are, after all, a community and are devastated when someone dies climbing).

Remember, "The Best Climber Climbs Tomorrow"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523815
>Elbow tendinitis

For me, this was triceps tendinitis (identity which tendon is bothering you). Triceps tendinitis took me over ten years to figure out, but i think i have it managed and it's very simple - stop the chicken wing. How? Focus on form, focus on putting your elbow into the wall. If you overcompensate, you might start hurting your bicep/delt. Focusing on putting my elbow into the wall (not down, but into the wall) has been making a big difference for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530327
This is after doing all sorts of strengthening, stretching, eccentrics, etc. I even identified that chicken wing was the problem and i thought i could passively fix it by strengthening rotator cuff - no dice. It's a form fix for me, got to consciously put that elbow into the wall. I was watching a v0 climber climbing horribly, but i noticed he wasn't in pain even though he was t-rexing like crazy. And i noticed that his elbows were staying close to the wall. I'm so stoked that i can abandon all the other training i was doing and simply focus on form and get stronger.

I tried other form fixes too -flexing my rhomboids and rotator cuff, trying to turn my elbow "in" (closer to my body) , trying to keep my elbow "down" - it's like no, it's like no. You gotta put your elbow into the wall, harder than you think you are. That's the only way to save your father from the underworld and clean up your room

>>2525743
Ankle support Is sort of a catch 22. It's the stiff sole and elevated heel that fuck up your natural mobility and stability, so you need ankle support to compensate when walking in rough terrain, because you're on an elevated stiff platform and heel striking, which is the actual problem. You land on the heel, your calves are not engaged to support propert and you twist your ankle before you have time to react.

A stiff sole is pretty much only needed for climbing, mountaineering and using crampons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Unlike conventional hiking boots that have extremely built-up soles and elevated heels, minimalist shoes possess almost no variation in sole height from heel to toe as well as a relatively thin sole. Because your foot is closer to the ground, it’s less likely to roll. In physics terms, the moment arm in minimalist shoes is extremely small or almost nonexistent, which is not true of conventional shoes, including most running shoes and hiking boots. A moment arm is the perpendicular distance from the point of rotation to the line of action of a force, and the moment is the tendency of the force to cause rotation (i.e., ankle rolling) about an imaginary axis through a point.

>Most conventional shoes and hiking boots possess tapering toe boxes that force your toes into a wedge position, causing toe deformities and misalignment and other problems over time. This toe wedging is a true problem, as it strips your foot of its inherent ability to protect you from ankle rolls. When your toes are positioned or aligned the way nature intended, and when your foot is allowed to sit on a level plane, you create a stable base of support—a tripod, essentially—that naturally resists ankle rolling.

Holy shit, another anon who actually gets it. A few months back I was ranting in one of these footwear threads about how the Aztec pochteca walked barefoot to trade their goods, the Native Americans wore moccasins, and the Roman legions wore sandals (tall, heavy, hobnailed sandals, but sandals nonetheless).

"I bet they'd have worn boots if they'd had them," was the brainlet response.

No, they'd have gone on being shod with flexible soles, because unless you have the squishy feet of an obese air conditioning-sitting office faggot, flexible soles are superior by far for rocky, uneven terrain.

But no doubt we will continue to hear about how you have to wear boots for ankle support, even though the stiff planks that pass for soles on those things contribute much more to injury than ankle support ameliorates.

There's a time and place for boots: When you absolutely need them. I have five pairs: knee-high muck boots, mukluks, duck boots, work boots, wading boots. But I wear wimpy, light, flexy things whenever I can get away with it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Big Scrub rainforest in coastal northern NSW is a great example of this. It was between 800,000-900,000ha (2.2million acres) of subtropical rainforest, now less than 1% of it remains. It was all cleared in the mid-late 1800s - the Robertson Land Act at the time stated that land leased from the government could only turn to freehold (i.e. privately owned) if it was completely clearfelled (among other conditions). The rich rainforest soil was great for agriculture and dairying, so essentially all of it was knocked down and burned within a period of 30 years. Lease conditions almost always did not allow for the sale of timber, so millions upon millions of superfeet of red cedar and white beech (some of the finest timber in the world) along with other softwoods and hardwood went wasted.

Picrel shows previous extent (yellow) against current extent (green) - the entire ecosystem is essentially functionally extinct

If you are really not larping:
get a house as passive as possible, very insulated, be as independent as possible ie don't buy shit you cannot fix or are reliable, have a big pantry and get long time shelve food in there, if you have a farm start looking into putting some fruit trees as they will take years until they are productive (better if are the kind that you can plant vegetables or grain bellow it), stcok seeds for your farm, prepare low tech irrigation systems for said farm, try to get solar or whatever but keep it as simple as possible, both to have less possible problems but also too look less prepared, a 7kw solar installation will catch attention which a 750w one would probably not.
Think also for transportation how can you move and how independent you will be if the petrol supply chain breaks, transportation uses a ton of energy
Be part of your community, try to be helpful and have their back, but usually is not a good idea to reveal all the preparations you are doing, just say that you are trying to save money buy bulk foods and getting solar or whatever

Also, if you can get a reasonable loan on a home and parcel of land in a rural area, do that shit. Obviously, you should be able to make payments on it with your income. And have enough liquid to make a few payments incase you temporarily lose employment due to a personal crisis

No amount of 'prepping' you can actually do will ever be enough, given enough time. All you can do really is increase the chances of survival by lengths of time and hope society unfucks itself or settles down before that time expires. Far enough north to avoid people, good luck when you run out of diesel fuel, bar oil, or any of the consumables needed for 'offgrid' living. Farther south, it'd be an unending swarm of locust-like refugees denuding the landscape and eating anything that moves. Comfy holler surrounded by like-minded family/friends/neighbors? You'd last the longest, but eventually machinery breaks and aforementioned consumables run out. Best case scenario is living in the 19th century until the hordes win out.
Hungry people don't stay still.

i know this is an unpopular opinion here; mainly because it goes against the weird LARP obsession that devolves into theorycraft about how rugged and self sufficient we all think we are. But the tendency is to focus on immediate needs without any thought at at all the longer term. How much can you do to hedge your chances of survival with nothing but hand-tools and no replacement parts (that you can't craft yourself without electricity) -- that's the calculus.

posts.com:
>>2528822
>prioritize
1. Know your area. Understand what resources you will be working with.
2. Flint knapping. If you can't make hard, sharp edges you're toast. Absolutely essential.
3. Cord. Pretty simple skill to pick up and the precursor to many other utilities.
4. Fire kit. You can use the cord you make for a bow drill which will make your life much easier as you will be starting campfires often.
5. Snares, traps, nets. Squirrels and fish are much easier to come by and process than big game. You will have to hunt at times but trapping is more reliable and less burdensome.
6. Basket weaving. You'll want to keep the various goods you forage for in separate containers.
7. Improvising shelters. You could probably throw something together without giving it a great deal of thought but the more you know about bush architecture the comfier your camps will be.
8. Pine tar adhesive. Once you have this in your repertoire you will be able to seal your baskets and make them watertight, among many other useful applications.
9. Processing hides. You won't be able to do top-quality leatherwork but you should be able to do well enough to clothe yourself and perhaps make a nice tent if you feel like hauling one around.
10. Everything else. Bushcraft is an extensive subject and if you have time before the collapse anything more you can pick up will contribute to your advantage. Good luck, Anon.

Good week for mushrooms ahead edition

>Community-based tools for IDing and Cataloguing
Mushroomobserver.org
The Bolete Filter: https://boletes.wpamushroomclub.org/
Inaturalist app (directly draws data from mushroomobserver but is itself a more generalized platform)
Google Scholar: Massive resource for papers and studies regarding current clinical and indigenous uses of medicinal fungi.

If you expect to get a remotely meaningful ID here, you need to be taking photos of the mushroom as you found it, on it's substrate, a clear shot of the top and side view of it, and a clear shot of the gills/pores/stipe/stem or otherwise the entire undercarriage of the mushroom. every detail of the encounter helps, where, when, what was the weather, etc.
If you want people who do this for a living to give their guess on ID's, take all of the above and make quality observations on Mushroomobserver.

This science needs as much redundant ID and loacation data as possible, any observation has value and is a meaningful contribution that takes a few more seconds than just taking a picture of the pretty thing you saw in the woods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2506039
>How can I make mushrooms to proliferate in an area so the following year has a larger amount of them?

The fruiting body you see on the surface is just one small part of the fungi. Beneath the surface is a mycelium system that spawns the fruiting bodies in an area that consistently produces mushrooms. I assume the best way to proliferate a desired fruiting body is to first proliferate mycelium growth (maybe by spreading nutrient substrate around the area), or to spread spores over the desired area during ideal weather conditions and over an ideal substrate in ideal locations to promote growth (ie under a damp log or on moist sheltered leaf litter during a cool rainy season, dependent on species). Both methods are dependent on local weather and light conditions, because they are done outside of a controlled environment. Large colonies also take a long time to grow and cover a large area, there are many examples in both the eastern and western US of colonies that are hundreds to thousands of acres in size and they are estimated to have taken hundreds to thousands of years to attain that much area. Might be worth a try, I'm not an expert.

i've never done anything but innoculating directly into pre-sterilized injection port bag of either millet/milo or rye, shaking up the bag once there's colonization, and then repacking it into a block. and just open up the grow bag for o2 when it's colonized, they'll fill the entire empty space on top of the block with fruit.

that's the best way to do low-sporulating strains as far as i've ever heard, if you try that with golden teachers or otherwise high sporulating strains you're just going to have a thick layer of spores on top of the block which is begging for contamination before a 2nd flush happens

point being the first flush is literally 99.99% guaranteed unless you somehow injected contamination in with the spores, zero stress zero doubts, zero equipment, just substrate bag and spore syringe.

if you're so inclined you can throw the colonized grain in with your choice of tub substrate mix if you are specifically trying to get 2-3+ flushes, it's still the safest way to get colonized grain in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2509836
>tub first timer grow, golden teachers
stop
buy sterilized rye grain or milo millet in injection port bags, innoculate modestly, don't shoot 10ccs into a 3lb bag, let it colonize, shake it up, let it fully colonize from there, and simply open up the top of the bag when it's ready to fruit. you don't need some magic combination of substrates to make this work, you put them alone in a bag of food, they find all the food they have access to, then you give them O2, keep them wet and warm and they fruit, it's that simple.

ESPECIALLY for high sporulating strains like golden teacher, you are basically going to get 1 flush, and then the entire top surface of your substrate is going to be painted black/purple with spores and is basically guaranteed contamination. save the fancy tub grows for some of the nicer, pickier, and lower sporulating strains.

protip you can turn 1 syringe of spores into pretty much unlimited colonizing fruit blocks if you either immediately move colonized grains into a bag/container of grains you made yourself (less than sterile but it won't matter, strain boiling water over it and you'll be fine, nothing to lose and it means you buy less spores from TOTALLYLEGALDRUGGROWING.COM)
or literally collect the spores in Agar and put em in your fridge to colonize. get a head start on your first attempt and you'll have unlimited attempts to get it right, or simply do the same thing again and get more shrooms.

seriously, don't overthink how fucking easy it is to grow some of the "beginner" strains, don't overthink sterilization and optimal anything, just do the first paragraph of this post and you "Will" have mushrooms, anything else turns that into a "Probably". but you should have unlimited "probably'"s with just the 1 syringe and a bag of rye or millet from the tractor supply store near you, i'd say good luck but it's too easy for luck

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2510742
Preserving spores is worse in every circumstance than preserving living liquid/agar culture

Starting with spores is a genetic gamble plus they take extra time to germinate. Your mushrooms will all grow at different rates too.

Whereas using living mycelium skips germination and is a clone of the specific mushroom you took it from and you have a better chance of your mushrooms growing at the same rate (leading to the coveted mushroom canopy).

>gather the mushrooms before the veil is fully separated to avoid spores falling because that's what signals to the mycelium to stop fruiting
This is true

>Don't the electrics turn off automatically?
No, there is no built in shut-off timer, just a useless bell and a thermoswitch that regulates the tempature. It will run itself dry if you let, my last one did that after my timer failed and it ruined the element and thermoswitch.

>vet gun

https://youtu.be/_j7gikQ7PUo?t=1024

When I make LC's I just free pour straight from the media bottle into grain bags. Less contam vectors and it's just simpler/quicker, and lets me use a more viscous, agar rich LC which I find helpful to speed up colonization. I have the same fittings on some bottles, but I just use them to suck up into normal syringes. I didn't realize these things were so cheap and widely available though so that changes my opinion of them, just ordered one. I like to mess around and try different things. I don't really do bulk LC though, I don't find it saves any time or resources personally. I do like LC's for storing culture though, easier to withdraw tissue from than a slant imo.

I hunt mushrooms because it takes me to places other people don't go or skip over. There's four different prizes to win:
>1. Fresh, edible mushrooms that you can't get in any stores
>2. Deadly mushrooms that you can say you've seen and identify
>3. Unusual-looking mushrooms that are fun to look at
>4. Psychoactive mushrooms that you can grab off the ground for free

There are no mushrooms that are dangerous to touch or even taste as long as you don't swallow them. I started by just going out and finding mushrooms, then trying to identify them with an app or book while out there. I started reversing that, targeting a mushroom that grows in my area to go out and find. Once spring starts there are certain species I want to find and clone and grow them myself.

The number one rule is don't eat anything that you aren't 100% sure on

>>2522239
gold oyster are SEA native warm tropic natives as far as I know but if you're in CA or florida I can see it being normal,

wait for the actual msurhoom fruit and get spores directly from the best individual mushrooms you can find, I've successfully done this with oysters just smashing up the fruit body and mixing it with oak substrate, oysters will out-compete just about anything in the long run in a body of substrate. that is how you narrow down the phenotype into the biggest most agressive mushrooms.

you can harvest the myceleum and just put that straight into substrate but that's a huge gamble, you'll almost definitely grow something but it's a coin toss. if you see a perfect mushroom, you want spores from that actual mushroom, not necessarily from that mushroom's mycelium body.

>>2523197
So I use the producer prides whole oats and all I do is add 920g of oats per bag, then add 600g of water(this is the equivalent of 4 mycoquarts per bag). Then I flash prep a quart and a half of wbs(bring water to a boil, take off the heat, add the wbs to the water and cover with a lid for 15 minutes. And after that I just add half a quart of the flash prepped wbs to the top of the oat bags. PC for 3 ½ - 4 hours. And then done.

Some people say you have to do a hot shake in order to redistribute the moisture in the grains but I don't do that and haven't had any problems. A hot shake is when you take the bags out as soon as the PC is depressurized and shake it around in front of your hood, but I just leave it in the PC to cool over night before I fuck with them. Plus if I do the hot shake then I mix all the wbs around which makes the lc recover slower since its all spread out. When I noc the bags I pour lc on the wbs at the top of the bag and it recovers fast

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2530319
Oh and I forgot to mention to strain the wbs after you let it sit in the pot of boiled water for 15 minutes, but you probably already knew that. Personally I strain it by dumping the pot in my kitchen sink with just the little drain strainer since its easier and less mess but you can use a strainer if you want I guess. I've seen people secure a window screen over a tote or a strainer inside a bucket, but to me that's just another thing to clean and another way for bird seed to get everywhere. And some ppl say you gotta wait ~30 mins for the water to strain. But since its only flash prepped and not fully hydrated you don't need to wait, just start loading it in the bag after like 3 minutes of letting the water drain. They'll finish hydrating fully during the PC cycle. I do it the same way for jars too and they always come out perfect, barely any bursted grains.

And 1 more note: I said the flash prep for this is 15 minutes in the boiled water but that's only because its a small amount of wbs. If you're doing flash prep for a bigger load like 10 quart jars or if you're doing 100% wbs bags then you want it to sit in the boiled water for like 25-30 mins instead

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531763
Not the poster, but the typical method is.

You would take a small piece of mushroom from the inside of a good looking specimen. This tissue culture will be placed onto an agar petri dish. From this sample mycelium will grow. After it's grown out a bit, you will take a small sample from the first agar plate and transfer it to a new one. Assuming the culture is clean and free from contaminants, wedges from this dish will be used to inoculate sterilized grain. This grain is allowed to colonize with the mushroom mycelium. Once colonized, the grains will be added to bags of hydrated sawdust and wheat bran. The mushrooms grow from these bags.

>why is agar used? does it have to be agar?
Agar is just a substance that can be easily steralised and has plenty of nuetrients for the mycelium to use to grow. There probably is agar alternatives, but agar is cheap and works well.

>Why is the mycelium from the second agar plate used? Is it to reduce the likelihood of contaminants (fungi/bacteria)
Yes, the first plate and syringes/swabs may contain mold spores and other contaminants from the air.

>Does this mean the whole process can be repeated by taking small pieces of mushroom from the new grown mushrooms & regrowing the mycelium in agar again
Yes, I'd reccomend looking into culture slants too for long term storage of mycelium.

I don't preseal to dry bag, I just accordion fold the dry bags in the PC to prevent water of the PC from leaking into the bags and/or water leaking out of the bags. I'm saying I seal them after I take them out the pc cycle because I was afraid of leaving the bags on my shelf unsealed before I have a bunch prepped for inoc day.

And if you're wondering how I'm able to stack 6 dry bags without submerging the bottom bags in the water; I just use 2 quarts of water for the presto instead of the standard 3 quarts, this in conjunction with putting a few quarters on the rocker prevents the PC from drying out. I always have plenty of water left, even after a 4 hr cycle

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532737
Honestly, a great way to start is to just learn the night sky. Learn how to identify constellations, the names of stars in them, etc. You can use star map apps to help you with this and you don't need any equipment. Actually knowing what you're looking at is pretty difficult when you first start out. It's very hard to enjoy a telescope if you don't know wtf you're pointing it at.

After you get familiar with constellations you'll want to see some more detail in them, that's where a 7x, 8x, or 10x binoculars comes in. They'll bring in a lot more light and thus way more stars than you could see with the naked eye. Objects that looked like a single start are now multiple stars, etc. Once you get intimate with the constellations in detail, you'll appreciate a telescope waaayy more and you'll be using it with a purpose.

As for finding interest in astronomy... it's personal.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531646
My US canteen doesn't use a gasket, so there's a few possibilities.
1. Remove the gasket, it's incorrect for your model and interfering with the actual seal.
Still leaks? Your model must need that gasket.
2a. Replace the gasket. A generic rubber o-ring from an auto parts or hardware store roughly 35-38mm should work
2b. Try a replacement cap. May cost as much as option 3.
2c. If you have the right tools, evenly remove a little material from the mating surface of the canteen rim.
3. Replace the canteen.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

One I forgot, you could try wrapping the threads with PTFE or electrical tape. More of an improvised solution though, probably won't hold up to regular use.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I just use a half sickle.
The main differentiator here it's whether The blade is symmetrical to the handle or offset, with an offset blade you can cut things parallel and right against the ground (grass). There's often a mild warp in the blade so your cut remains parallel through a sweeping arc.

Downside is you can't use as much force, but the half sickle is still fine for anything up to about two thumbs.
My rationale here is that rarely will I be surprised by wood that thick, if I'm cutting wood like that I'm either clearing land and will need a maatock, or I'm chopping fire wood and will need an axe.

If you're cutting grass it's usually because you want the grass, and between cutting branches and cutting grass it's the grass which needs the specialized tool

Poland here, less than 100km from Ukrainian border. Family of four with two small kids. City apartament. That's what I managed to acomplish in past two years, starting from almost zero:

>7 days worth of bottled water following 3,7L per person per day rule, home water filter

>extra butane canisters for camping stove I already owned

>at least 7-14 days worth of food, cycled (can't tell exactly as it's my wife's expertise). 1/3 is in the freezer but rest is shelf stable including some ready to eat high calorie items

>stock of vitamine suplements + few packets watercress seeds

>started stockpiling and cycling virtually every consumable item at house including medicines, hygiene products, soap, wet wipes, diapers etc.

>stocked up on bandages/band aids, bought another first aid kit

>charging system: solar 21W mat, hand crank charger, powerbanks and headlamps operating on 18650 rechargable cells, extra cables, micro to usb-c adapters

>spend cash on purchases before prices go up. Every day items, outdoor clothing. Ended up with 3 pairs of hiking footwear scaling up to any weather conditions

>diversified savings: bought some USD, 20g gold bar, keeping over 1k€ worth cash at home in case no ATM service. Invested rest into lending fund and actually started earning on it lately because more and more people are plunging into debt

>lost 20kg of weight, started doing cardio and power walks around my neighboorhood after dusk. Great way to know your exit routes, hidden shortcuts and... local lowlifes

>put together things I already had into "EDC pouch" I carry in my backpack everywhere I go, including work

>stocked my empty locker at work with extra food I already used (oats, carrot juice, tea). It was unused space and now it's 3 days worth of food storage

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>completed 12kg bug-out-bag for myself and 5kg version for my wife. Including tools, emergency rations, water + portable filter, first aid kits, important documents, matching sleeping bags, four N95 respirators and comfort items for kids

>>2512573

Also Polak here, I invested in czarnoprochowiec. If Putin invades Iam gonna enlist in communist militia and take your preps Janusz and you wont do anything about it.

Morbid jokes aside, I would ditch the butane camping stove and get one that uses gasoline or diesel, because its gonna be easier to get liquid fuel than proprietary canisters if supply chains break. Especially if you have car, then you already have a supply of fuel to last you months.
One gallon of gasoline is enough to cook meals and boil water for your family for one month. They also work reliably in low tempreatures, unlike gas stoves. Personally use pic rel - its soviet made, stupid simple, to use and maintain.
There are also chink kerosene/diesel wick stoves available on allegro, people successfully cook on them even in their homes.

21Watt solar panel is too weak to reliably charge smartphone in winter. Speak from experience, because I run 60 watt setup with 50ah agm battery and it only works well enough from march until october. We have like 3 hours of sunlight in winter from 8 to 11 and even that provided there is no over overcast. If you want to reliably maintain energy supply for small 12v appliances like radio, phone, tablet, hairclipper, mp3, flashlights and so on, you need to have a battery in the apartment, which will be trickle charged by appropriately sized panel. If you need to move, get powerbank.

As said before, it was already sitting in my basement with almost full canister, just bought second one (winter mix with isobutane). It's small camping model so it can even be carry in backpack (but I don't intend to). As for those home use I like how clean it burns. I can easily improvise alcohol stove from almost any cans and wicking material. Around half a liter of 90% isopropyl alcohol + toilet paper roll gave me around 4,5hrs of BIG FLAME. I will probably add gasoline one as third option, didn't know the fuel is so efficient. Althrough in persimible envinronment I would probably just cook outdoors with twigs. Hobo stove (either folding one or made of cans). Yet to try proper welded rocket stove. Heard a lot of good about them. If I wasn't renting I would be installing proper indoors cast iron wood stove with an outside chimney, that kinda solves both heating, fuel and cooking isues at once
>21Watt solar panel is too weak
That's why I've decided to get proper crank charger instead of recommended everywhere crank radio. I have radio in all my smartphones, just need to connect wire headphones (or any wire with 3,5mm jack really). I had to import K-Tor charger from the US, it's the only one that works imo, tested few from EU market then returned. In my BoB I also have lightweight gizmos to charge my devices from: ~230V, 12/24V car installation, AA batteries, 18650 LioN (which I have plenty of charged) or 2x CR123A and I can use AAA in backup flashlight. The idea is to use it all to charge phones & flashlights as we go where we need to go. If there is no electricity for longer period you won't be making calls anyway.
Proper power station with solar panels would have to wait until we move as well. They're expensive as fuck and of limited charge cycles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2516913
>Proper power station with solar panels

They are a bit of a meme, being just a nice plastic box with controller, switches, outlets and an inverter DC/AC inverter (which is pointless in smaller installations, because it wastes too much energy). I put together mine using an old bathroom cabinet to house controller and battery. Only use 12v DC appliances, because they are the most efficient with small panels and a battery that still remains somewhat portable. Mine cost me about 650pln (last year prices) and has capacity of 60watt/50ah/10amp. Not fancy looking or very portable, but works well with simple comms (phone, pmr), led lights, hair clipper and entertainment devices like tablet, reader and radio. Obviously limited use in winter, due to our climate, would have to scale it up. LiFePo battery would be more optimal die to extended practical capacity and much lower weight, alas they are more expensive. As for the manual chargers I dont have any experience, toyed with the thought of putting one together myself based on bike and car alternator. Dont really have much faith in my ability to crank the generator with hands for long time.

They are decent in comparison to EU norm - lots of red tape to get loicense, but after that you can get basically anything that isnt full auto or anti tank. Folding stocks, short barrels, hicap mags, suppressors - no problem so far. Sporting, collecting and hunting licenses are most common.
There is a loophole for carrying handguns if you have a sporting license. Getting license for self defense purposes is nigh impossible unles you are well connected. Blackpowder firearms and their ammunition are license free, which makes them very popular among prepperfags and boomer cowboy afficionados - there are estimates that something like half a million of them were sold since 2008.
Still not many people own modern firearms, because its an expensive hobby in comparison to wages and also average normie from 1940s to early 2000s was being conditioned to associate them with criminals and glowies. But shooting and tacticool larping get increasingly popular for obvious reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521165
>why use solar? why not use lead acid batteries?


Cause batteries wont charge themselves? And if you dont keep them trickle charged they will selfdischarge and deteriorate within months. There is no point of having batteries if you dont have means to charge them after electricity goes out. Solar panels are the most convenient means to do that if you live in apartment and obviously cant run fuel generator. Silent, safe and need minimal maintenance in comparison to generators. Their deterioration is negligible for practical purposes.
Old style unsealed acid lead batteries are unsafe to use inside living quarters and dont take well to repepated prolonged discharges - which is what you need for running or charging 12v appliances. Thats why they were replaced by sealed deep cycle acid-gel batteries and now by LiFePo. Not to mention its hard to even buy them nowadays.

posts.com:
id strongly recommend people test their preps, i did for a week and it was miserable as fuck after 3 days and some mistakes, the rules were i could only eat/drink what i had stored and i could only heat anything i consumed or washed myself with by stored gas.
what i learned
>fuck dried goods
rice and beans are a trap, let the meme die, they are a water sink. if you have a well or stream and lots of fuel to boil water, they may be ok
>love canned goods
this was a mixed lesson, not all of the canned goods were good when eaten cold, the stuff that had to be heated up to not taste like corn syrup made my fucking throat hurt trying to swallow (this was even after only stocking stuff that had 'good' ingredients, with the least amount of goyslop possible) but some stuff was ok eaten cold, which saved fuel.
canned food success- chili, spag bol, mac n cheese, hot dogs, potatoes, carrots, spam (the canned chili was easily the best thing i had all week but i later saw on youtube that canned goods with tomato in them have a high chance to go bad, theres some acid in the tomato that can react with the lining of a can)
canned food failures- meat + veg stews, all soups, the range of cheap shit i wanted to try so i could get more for my $
>you dont need to drink as much water as you think
not when living a normal, non apocalyptic, life that is. most of the water i used was for cleaning myself, which i used more of than i was expecting as i had under-prepped wet wipes. just buy wet wipes, lets and lots and lots of them, theyre dirt cheap and can be used for everything.
>luxury items
you need them. coffee (obvious) and chocolate, dark chocolate can last a long time and i although i had planned to eat 1/3rd of a bar per sitting/day purely based on calorie counting, having a few blocks after a meal became a vital part of my eating routine as no matter how bland the sometimes-cold canned food was, i knew i had a nice cup of coffee and some dark chocolate.

>>2504957
I haven't been there other than driving through but if you want resort skiing, there's Schweitzer. I am sure you could find good backcountry downhill skiing (that would require skinning up or hiking up, or taking turns taking each other up on snowmobiles) but that of course requires having a friend, and both of you having avalanche training and avalanche gear. And I am sure you could also find good cross country skiing, but even if you're "cross country skiing" there could be avalanche danger, so if you don't know what you're doing, you should look for some maintained cross country trails (or go downhilling at Schweitzer).
In truth you kinda sound like a tard who would end up going into the backcountry alone and getting buried in an avalanche, so you should probably stick to in-bounds resort downhill skiing, or xc on groomed maintained trails (do web search "nordic ski area idaho panhandle" see if you find anything) until you become less of a tard

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2504957
>Im confused about what im looking for, do i want back country skis, touring skis, cross country?

If you just want to tour and are not interested in making Alpine descents then you want cross country skis. Specifically, backcountry touring x-country skis. They will typically be wider than fits in a groomed x-country track but they will/should have metal edges that handle a wider range of conditions and terrain- but they will still be double cambered so you still kick and glide like traditional x-country...this is the perfect ski for sking up ungroomed trails and forest service roads and exploring relatively flat terrain.

>Is it an activity typically done outside?
Walking from the entrance to a building to your car is also an activity typically done outside, so I'm afraid it's not quite that simple. Other activities typically done outside:
>taking the dog for a walk
>landscaping, yard work
>music concerts
>sports events
>circuses, fairs, carnivals, etc.
>farmer's markets, street markets
>farming and agriculture
>roofing, painting, etc.
So as you can see, there mere fact of doing something without having a roof over your head doesn't qualify an activity as /out/. Personally I've long been on the fence about metal detecting, because it requires an electrical device and typically involves not going innawoods but in fact deliberately staying near populated areas where people are/were likely to have dropped, lost, or buried shit.

Anyway, Louisiana’s bayous, swamps, marshes, and wetlands are terrible and never any fun. Don’t come here, ever. Trust me, it’s bad.

Just because you saw a Vagrant Holiday video where he trainhopped for a week doesn't mean you'll magically be able to live as a hobo for an entire summer. Of those "large groups of people", do you know how many have been dragged to death by trains, or how many have fallen, or how many were dismembered on the tracks or in between cars, or how many were beaten by bulls? Hitchhiking is marginally safer, but it's still a gamble. There are a lot of nasty people outside of your sheltered neighborhood.

Here's my advice: if you just want to see the country, buy a beater and car camp across the country. You can do it legally and safely on BLM and most forest service land. Gas will cost you, sure, but you'll get many of the same views on the interstate that you would on a train, and without having to hide from bulls or take shelter from extreme weather.
>But my car might break down!
If you can't handle dealing with a breakdown, you would never have survived train hopping. And if your trip ends early, Mom and Dad can come pick you up and not your corpse.

And if you just want views of nature along with the feeling of being self-sufficient, why not just learn how to camp?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532017
I've spent about 4 months on and off over the past 3 years living in a minivan about the same size as the van in OP's pic. I've mainly stayed in cities, but I've spent some time out in the country in AZ/NM/CO.

>how feasible is this idea full time?
Not paying rent is pretty great. I feel like that's pretty much the only benefit. The worst part about van life is finding things to do when you're in an urban area if you're only working part-time. You'll have to find a way to shower, do laundry, and stay clean. If you don't have refrigeration or a stove, eating shelf-stable camp food gets boring after a few days while eating out everyday is expensive and unhealthy. If your van isn't insulated, the afternoons are hot and the early mornings are very cold.

>Would I get sick of it after a year?
Yes, especially if you don't have basic utilities. I have a pretty high tolerance to camping grit, and the longest I've lasted in a van was 66 consecutive days last spring (a combination of camping in AZ, NM, and then working in urban TX). In my opinion, it's a lot more sustainable to treat van life as an extended camping trip rather than full-time living. You'll look forward to van trips if you still live under a roof 10 months out of the year instead of feeling semi-homeless all of the time (pic related).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530325
Baofengs get the job done for a great price but they felt like an expendable item when I held one. Biggest complaints from hamboomers is that they spray a lot of noise on transmit thus they can bleed over into other freqs, and that the receive is too sensitive so can perform poorly when other, undesired strong signals are nearby. This is an issue in all radios but supposedly worse on Baofengs. As a bonus, I believe they can be programmed to function on FRS/GMRS frequencies, which means you can talk to the regular walmart walkie talkies too.

Next level for ya'll innawoods might be setting up something like simplex(directly person to person, no repeater) DMR so you have a little more range and obfuscation(other DMR capable radios can understand you, but no one else can). More expensive radios, and it's a little complex to set up. But you learn a bit more and I think it's a good first step on the road to encrypted radio.

Best tip for VHF/UHF is that line of sight is king, and something like a N9TAX Slim Jim/Jpole can be put high up in a tree to get a lot more range, should you require it.

Baofengs themselves won't break the rules that people care about if you stay on the FRS (family radio service) channels and switch to low txpwr max output wattage on FRS is 2w and low power is 1w. I am taking my technical HAM license test Saturday

If you have friends and want to communicate with them while in the woods, baofengs are fine. If you are going to just use it for emergency purposes, something like a Garmin Inreach would serve you better.

Handhelds are not going to propagate past the horizon, they are VHF and UHF only. If you want better performance, replace the stock antenna. Also, privacy tones are not private, everyone can hear you if they tune into your frequency.

SOTA/POTA looks fun (look it up) and I am considering doing something like that with an ICOM ID-705.

yeah over rocks and sharp areas having a wrap for the rope is gonna be a good idea and also gonna extend your rope life. get good gloves like the ones in the pic (petzl makes good climbing gear) make sure everything that gonna hold weight is rated for way more than you will ever use it for. yes the breaking hand usually will be at the back when rappelling. learn what a prussik and VT prussik knot's are and how to tie them. pulleys are gonna be used later as you get more knowledge and applied skill. fingerless gloves are a big no no always full finger (ropes will burn you so fast you cannot imagine) let me know if you have any other questions.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2510676
it's getting harder, but still doable
we lucked out a bit and found a 3.5 acre plot about 35 miles from town (western oregon), that already had planning permission on it. it's forest land, so the state/county was super picky about allowing SFD's out here.

the way we did it was to go through a building company (adair homes) and get a construction loan.
>land: 60k
>construction cost on the house: 130k
>site dev: 50k (grading/ excavation/clearing the firebreak)
>septic/well/etc permit costs: 15k
>down payment: ~25k

the construction loan covered all the costs, and upon building completion converted to a conventional mortgage. it sounds expensive, but after the build was completed the property was valued at around 500k, vs the 260ish we financed. You definitely come out ahead when building vs buying (and no PMI). Our mortgage now is only $1300ish out the door.

Construction loans usually have a 12 month term, at which point you need to have the entire project completed. getting through the county took 4 months, and that was with the permit already in place -- otherwise it would have been a year for that approval alone. TL;DR plan on buying your land in cash, then hold off on taking out a construction loan until you know you'll be able to build (there's some obvious risk here, buy the land and the county could just say "no, you can't build here, for reasons".)

All this was done on 2 middle class salaries (135k household income), but that's kind of the minimum in 2022 to even buy a house, period. (which is a terrible omen of things to come in the US)

i don't think you understand the hell that is involved in trying to split tracts of land up; that farmer would lose money on such a deal, a single acre is so small and worth so little, the fees would outstrip the sale price of a single acre plot. then there's all sorts of access easements, right of way concerns, zoning etc; it's a fucking headache. weyerhaeuser does this kind of thing after logging; but it's typically a larger tract (think like 100+ acres) but they parcel it off into 5 to 20 acre plots, then sell those. 1 acre is not worth anyone's time. This is all assuming it's actually rural.. closer to town the price of land increases enough to make it profitable to parcel out tiny mcmansion yards.

But all that is assuming the county would even allow it, oregon for example would almost certainly cock block that (planning goals here are basically designed to preserve farm and forest land.) Trying to develop formerly productive farm land into a SFD is going to take literally years, LUBA (thanks landwatch) proceedings take forever (assuming you win.)

If you had actually gone through the process of a build, or developing land at all you'd know it's not nearly as simple as you make it out to be.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532012
How much does a horse cost?
It's a complex question and will very much depend on what is the minimum you can live with and what you are willing to DIY. You say plug ins. Does that mean you want a grid attachment? In most places they'll only grid attach buildings that meet the code.
Before you get attached to the idea of grid, see if your needs can be met with a portable power station and a few solar panels. If you only use a low power laptop it's more than enough.
You say no insulation. But what about vapor barrier and sheathing for wind? How about windows? If you can 100% DIY and are comfortable living in a shed then the cost of an A-frame would be the cost of a chainsaw and a small amount of metal roofing from facebook marketplace or similar. You can get leftovers from other people's bigger projects for cheap.
If you want to learn conventional framing with 2x4s from the box store and put it on a concrete pier foundation like those used for sheds or outbuildings, and you wanted it finished with a typical shingle roof and vinyl siding, you're probably looking at north of 20k in materials cost.
Again though, it really really depends on what you are willing to learn, how much time you're willing to spend, and whether you are stubborn enough to do things 100% on your own.
If you want some inspiration watch a video on:
- cordwood construction. This is a method of building using cheap dry softwood logs as bricks in a DIY lime mortar. It's a niche technique here in the north. It's commonly used by single-family DIY teams that value a low-cost house over a low-labour house. It takes a lot of time to lay the wood bricks and for them to dry.
- shelter institute timber frame construction. This is a typical modern timber frame. They build with simple joinery but it would take a good amount of practice for a new framer to learn to maintain his chisels and cut the joints properly. The lowest labour finishing technique for these houses is to use SIPs.

Chickens are an amazing animal to keep around. They are like a barn cat in many ways.
First off we can eat chickens and there eggs, and that's cool on its own.
Secondly if you have a proper plot of land chickens can survive by scratching with little to no supplemented feed.
This is a big one the keep pests down, tick, lady bugs, even snakes can be keep at bay by a good flock.
Lastly all the poop is a good fertilizer.
In short if you have land chickens can be a low maintenance self sustaining food and sanitation solution.

Why do you think THEY would want to keep you from them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2532155
Only slaughter them after a LONG time (8 years) unless you have some kind of efficiency operation going. Like if you dont have multiple roosters, so that you make more chicks for free, then dont slaughter them like that. You can at the end of their lives slaughter them and make chicken soup or feed them to your dogs/cats (very healthy). Hens lay fewer eggs as time goes on but yeah you dont want to slaughter them needlessly like that without a breeding or efficiency operation. If its such a big deal to have 2 fewer eggs per week then just buy an extra bird.

Hi guys, I did one for Canada based on my very limited experience. Maybe some of you can add to it or provide some feedback?

My justifications:
>Ontario (home): gets a 6 because while it does have some amazing outdoor spaces, like Algonquin Park, and of course the entire North-West of the Province, most of the Southern part, where people actually live, is pretty developed farmland and urban area.
>Quebec: gets a 7 because once you get out past the Saint Lawrence seaway and associated large cities it's basically nothing but hills and wilderness and taiga.
>New Brunswick: I give it a 7 too, it's small but it does have some pretty impressive natural monuments like the Bay of Fundy and associated areas.
>PEI: gets a 5 because although it's beautiful and has an incredible beach (PEI National Park) most of it is densely-developed farmland. It's actually Canada's most densely populated province.
>Nova Scotia: gets a 9 because of Cape Breton which is fucking incredible.
>Newfoundland: gets a ? because I've never been there, but from what I've heard it would probably get a high score.
>Manitoba: gets a ? because I've never been there. Churchill up north is a popular enough tourist destination, and most of the province is empty taiga.
>Saskatchewan: probably the least impressive province in terms of natural beauty, it was mostly prairie in the past, it's mostly farmland now.
>Alberta: gets a 9 because of Banff and Jasper alone, although the prairie is quite beautiful as well and Dinosaur Provincial Park is worth a visit.
>BC: gets a 9, maybe should even be a 10 because honestly Vancouver Island, the coastline, and the rainforest, are fucking beyond incredible. One of the most beautiful places in the world, in my opinion.
>Yukon: gets an 8 because it's basically Canada's Alaska minus the Coastline (that's in Northern BC).
>Nunavut and NWT get a ? because I've never been there. I'm sure the tundra is beautiful though.

Correct. I live in approximately in the area I've circled on the map, which I like to call the Paradisical Confluence.

It's mountain laurel and pawpaw country, AKA top-tier, featuring plenty of public land, a long stretch of the AT and various smaller trails, lakes (mostly artificial impoundments, sadly) of all sizes in every direction, plenty of game and a few nice hunting preserves, streams big and small running through virtually every town and city and the spaces between.
