Also, all of the shit weather everyone else is suffering just passes by my holler under the protection of the gentle Appalachians. They may not be as tall as muh big rock out west, but on the other hand: no tornadoes, no blizzards, no nor'easters, no wildfires, no -50F temps, no tsunamis, no (actual) floods, etc.

>So just to clarify- when you say never you really mean sometimes.
Semantics. Since you're clearly on the autistic spectrum, I'll explain in great detail so that one of your kind can (maybe) comprehend.

The woods in the circle do occasionally catch fire, but we don't have constant, raging, miles-wide patches of firestorms for months due to decades of poor forestry practices, transplanted eucalyptus, and simply natural processes as is the case in California.

There hasn't been a true blizzard in the circle since last century. We have had feet of snow very occasionally, but not the wind to accompany it; and we've had high winter winds, but not the feet of snow to accompany them.

Technically, minor tornadoes can very occasionally appear inside the circle, but in practice no one even notices. Whereas in other areas of the country, entire trailer parks, suburban hellscapes, and Walmarts get demolished on a regular basis. That doesn't happen in the circle, at all.

Floods here are bothersome and can cause some damage, but they don't become major enough to wash away homes and businesses, wipe out bridges, or tear apart roads. There was a bad mudslide that wiped out a small portion of a tiny little mountain town a couple years back, but that wasn't a flood.

So in short, it may not be LITERALLY AND TECHNICALLY EXACTLY 0% CHANCE EVER OF EVEN THE MOST MINOR EVENT, but what we do get isn't even noticeable or remotely newsworthy compared to what happens elsewhere.

MI is technically included in the 18 or 19 states that can get 250 inches of average snowfall a year. The southern hemisphere snowfalls and snowpacks don't compare to northern hemisphere ones. IIRC the snowiest resorts and places in the southern hemisphere get less than the European Alps or the mountains of Turkey and Iran (>300 inches on average), all of which are beaten out by Utah or California. The highest recorded snowfall in Alaska was beaten out by WA state in measured totals, and parts of the mountains in CA near Tahoe are estimated to get 600-700 inches on average. Some estimates from Japan that aren't confirmed by direct measurements put their maximum average snowfalls at around 1500 inches, however in measured totals they are beat by the US in both any given year and overall. As for Alaska, the Chugach mountains are the snowiest along with the mountains of the Kenai facing Prince William Sound. There it is possible to get 300 inches of snow in a week or two.

>>2531250
The snowiest location in Siberia gets less than 400" of average snowfall. The snowiest range in Russia is Mt Elbrus and the mountains around Lake Baikal, both of which again average less than 400" (often less than 300" in a typical year, similar to the European Alps). The arctic does not actually get as much snow as the mid latitudes, due to the jet stream activity. The Himalayas don't get as much snow due to its jet streams coming from the tropics and its northern and eastern flanks being deserts and blocking the Siberian stream. However, isolated sections of the windward side of the Himalayas get more snow than Siberia and can be in the top 5 (eg Gulmarg, although the climate averages there are poorly/if ever documented, whereas in the US, Canada, and Japan they are meticulously documented), albeit the documented max snowfalls (average and record) are still lower than the US (both the lower 48 and separately also Alaska), Japan, and Canada. Japan and western North America get the most snow in the world, both due to the Siberian and North Pacific jet streams. The pacific jet stream is actually the most dominant one in influencing weather systems in North America, not the Atlantic jetstreams, it sends snow storms as far east as Maine and Quebec.

Most of the geography of the new world was named by Europeans, only a tiny share (>10%) is from non-European sources or influences. It is a generic name for mountains just like "white mountain" is in many tongues, there are at least a half dozen ranges named such in the US in English.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526131
>it's the fiber itself that deteriorates.
And what is the mechanism that deteriorates the UHMWPE fibers according to you?
Early Cuban fiber stuff delaminated in a way that the mylar separated at the stitching due improper stitch choice and reinforcement of the area.
It also had problems with sagging on doors early on, due to the type of Mylar used not bonding as well with the adhesive used, and being non-woven it allowed stretching along the bias.
Both of these problems have been remedied by shelter and pack manufacturers updating how things are constructed, and DSM switching from M to K type mylar for better adhesion and less brittle

>>2500079
>any of you /out/ists taken the offgrid cabin pill yet? howd it go?
I've been off grid for 5 years but get called a larper whenever I post so kind of gave up contributing. I bought a cheap single bedroom cottage in rural NE Victoria (australia) because it was close to a dairy farm I was managing that was already on septic and tank water. Everything works. I have a normal kitchen and office and can blare music and play video games like any other person. All my power tools are corded but the inverter has no trouble powering a pressure washer or angle grinder. A few solar panels and an inverter was all it took to take it completely off grid. Having the rain water tank at ground level is the biggest drain on my power though, every time I turn a tap there's a 50W jet pump that goes brrrr and draws the same power as a microwave running on high. Keep your rain water at roof-gutter level instead of ground level to allow gravity to keep the water pressure up so you can at least shit and shower if the power goes out. My house looks like any other 1960's Australian fibro cottage but I take a working holiday every couple of years to Taree as a cattle drover and stay in pic-related.

I want to talk about how hard it is to be green, but it really isn't. I just gifted most of my shit to grateful friends when I was 28ish and have room to move now

posts.com:
>>2516929
>that should absolutely be their prerogative
Not really, no.

The main goal is to protect and increase property taxes. The preventing a shanty town is part of this. As a secondary goals, they want to make sure you are dealing with your waste water properly. Some areas also want to make sure you are only using your share rain and ground water. And don't forget your municipality is probably providing waste and fire services. There's also the fact you are going to be selling your property at some point - it's all very well building and living in your own death trap shack but once you sell it the next guy won't know how much of a death trap it is.

Zone also governs land use - some land is reserved for agriculture, some for living, some for industry. You wouldn't want your country idyll destroyed by a neighbour setting up a motorcross track or gravel pit.

But you must know that these zoning laws only apply in some areas, not everywhere. Get as far from a city or town as possible and you should be fine. Don't expect to get away with a shack if you are in a beautiful valley, next to a beautiful lake, within a walking distance of the store. Many areas have a loophole that you can get away with a lot less infrastructure if your house is on wheels.

And really importantly, if you want to be left alone in your shack don't be a moron and mail out bombs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Have you gone over all the different aspects of a functional cabin? Where are you going to poop? Where is your water coming from? How will you store food? Does it need heating/cooling?

For example... My land had nothing but trees on it. So I put a trailer on it (old one that was practically being given away) then I had a well dug for water supply. That was expensive but worth it. Then I had a septic tank and field put in for the trailer... Somewhat expensive and a hassle to get it perked, but nice to be able to use my toilets and not have to go on a short hike everytime I needed to poop. Then I had electric hooked up.... That cost money too because they had to install poles and run the lines to the trailer. Also, they may refuse to hook up electric if they think your cabin is not safe enough.

Not trying to discourage you... It would just suck to put thousands of dollars into this only to realize you forgot that you need a clean water source to live. I was without it for a while and relied on bottled water.... It's insane how much water we use and how quickly things get crappy when you are having to ration what water you do have.

it's about building codes/minimum standards for dwellings more than anything.

i'm guessing mostly it's the fact that jurisdictions haven't really caught up to living offgrid. there really should be a variance for these types of dwellings. if someone wants to buy some land and build their house, install septic, etc etc on their timeline, that should be their right. no one is going to buy a fucking house on a plot of land and then realize "oh shit, it's not on the grid, fuck me, i didn't bother to see if there was electricity!"

like my county (lane, OR) has minimum dwelling sizes, septic/mains/well requirements, etc etc; which make it either outright impossible to buy land, and build a homestead from scratch, or make the permitting/siting process take so long that construction loans aren't feasible. For example: getting a conditional use permit for a dwelling on F2 land requires at least 18 months of paperwork and waiting around while some 25 y/o nitwit planner looks for reasons to deny your build, meanwhile construction loans typically have a 1 year conversion timeline. wife and i lucked out and found a property that already had the CUP on it, otherwise there was no way we could have swung the land purchase and rolled it into our construction loan.

it's such a fucky situation, one that a lot of the naive 20 somethings here completely fail to understand. then again if it were as simple as rolling an RV onto a plot of land and going for it, there wouldn't be any countryside left. Some states are probably more amenable to this kind of thing, but the overall trend seems to be to make moving out into rural areas more and more difficult -- environmentalism gone wild coupled with a subtle/backhanded mommy government hatred of proles and independence.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2505999
Sure.

We do seasonal pigs here. That is, we purchase feeder piglets from a local farm in the spring, and then they go to the butcher in the fall. We do this specifically to avoid overwintering pigs and dealing with full grown breeders. It's a lot less work on our part and we don't carry the burden of the breeding stock.

Because of this we have a 1.5 acre forest pasture rich in acorns for the pigs to live on. They shop up when they're young and easily handled. Already cut and weaned. We purchase pig feed from a local feed mill that has very reasonable prices and sources somewhat locally. Pigs handle the feed well and grow quickly. We only usually need to deworm them once during this process. As the weather is mild they generally don't need much housing. They destroy anything you give them anyways, so their run in always looks like shit.

We keep 2 for our family and sell the other 3+ which pays for all 5+ pigs every year. Essentially we 'eat for free'. We sell half shares of pork to friends and locals who buy into all the buzzwordy meat stuff. This is why they go to a butcher, because there's some regulations there on how meat sales and preparation are handled. I send my two along as well because our butcher does a much much better job than I do and the pork sales cover it 100%, so why not.

People want to eat meme breeds so Berkshires are very popular, but hybrids are generally more vigorous and less likely to fail to thrive. Berkshire crosses is what we generally handle here.

In a small operation, this is the most cost effective and easiest method by far. Every year we look into buying a male and two females to start our own breeding program. Planning on keeping 5+ piglets and selling the rest, but the cost of everything skyrockets and piglet sales alone won't cover all the costs, so the operation starts operating at a loss and my goal is always to break even on food.

>>2510634

What does intellectual pursuit mean?

I have plenty of time to do whatever I want. Sometimes when I'm out doing chores I'll listen to audiobooks, especially if it's just splitting firewood or digging post holes or something else I can sort of tune out and enjoy the semi-meditative nature of the work. I read books before bed.

We can our own hides for buckskin and furs. My wife sews things for me and the kids like moccasins and wool clothing. We spend the winter months doing quiet things around the wood stove indoors. This time of year the days are so short and the outdoor work is really at it's lowest point we have plenty of idle time.

Summer is just busy as it can be. I routinely work sunup to sundown without much of a break. Unless you count the 9 to 5 as a break. There's gardening, animals to care for, chickens to hatch, firewood to log out and stack, always something needs fixing, or some animal in distress or whatever. Usually summer is the worst time to build things and run fence. That's best left for spring/fall.

There's plenty of time to do all manner of things. You just have to do them differently than you might expect. I don't have time to play video games much anymore, but I don't particularly miss them either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2510648

Yes. There's plenty of time to do all of these things. You can attend university online, if that's what you want to do with your life. The pandemic put higher education on the internet for two years, and it's still running that way if you want to go the more traditional route.

I can find anything I need on the internet. I have the opportunity to get a Masters for free, and I can do it all via remote learning. Though, in my case, most of the classes are 'read two books, write a paper, read two more books, write another paper' style courses. I just have to do the paperwork to get started, but an advanced degree really won't affect my lifestyle or career at all, so I'm not in a rush.

I don't particularly see the point of any city. They're massive ultra consumerist shit holes. They produce absolutely nothing of value. They survive off of an infinite number of trucks constantly pouring in filled with goods produced elsewhere. I haven't voluntarily set foot in a major city in nearly eight years and my life is better for it.

If you live this lifestyle, it depends on how you live it. It's different for everyone. That will determine how much 'leisure' time you have. If you're really shitty and lazy you'll be too busy fixing your own fuckups to have much time to do anything else. But, if you're earnest and honest in your work and do it right the first time and never procrastinate or half-ass anything, you can have a lot of good down time to enjoy the fruits of your labor.

The lifestyle is also very seasonal. You'll be very busy in Summer, but very very not in Winter, assuming you did everything right. Now is about when I enjoy a full freezer and pantry and catch up on movies I missed during the year.

>>2510832
My grandparents had a farm and were farmers. They were retired when I was a kid, so I spent half the year out in the country in the middle of a farm community basically left to my own devices. I then read Hatchet and My Side of the Mountain and the other mandatory out books and it made me obsessed with camping and backpacking. I spent as much time outside as possible and had an aptitude for the farm chores and outdoor lifestyle.

I grew up, went to college, got a good job in the city and resigned myself to living the good urbanite lifestyle until I met my now wife. We both started hanging out and slowly realized with BOTH hated living in the city and wanted to live out in the woods and raise sheep and things of that nature. So we just left. Now we have several children and are making the homesteading thing work.

Resources for homesteading is a tough one. Nothing will ever be a stand-in for hands on experience. Most youtube videos are charlatans if not outright liars and I've actually somehow ended up helping out a few IG homesteaders with things like all their chickens dying from easily treatable illnesses that opened my eyes to how much the influencer crowd is just ignorant if not outright malicious.

I'll go through my homesteading bookshelf later, after I put the boys down for bed, and see if anything jumps out at me. Five acres and independence is a good book. The figures are out of date, but the concepts and ideas are timeless.

I did some googling and the initial results seem to quote $5000-$7000 USD per hectare (2.5 acres) for Argentine farmland.

I'm not particularly surprised by roughly ~$2400/acre for farmland in Argentina. Things like local laws, government taxes, access to global capital, exposure to foreign companies, etc. means that you, an Argentine, may be competing with Monsanto or some New York holding company for the land.

The USA still has tons of cheap farmland because A) it's a huge empty country, B) rise of urbanization means tons of prior-farms are abandoned or sold dirt cheap, and C) the economics of agriculture incentivize for certain commodities to be produced locally and then sold to a major processor or middleman (ie. Purdue chicken).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2507191
Yea keeping pigs ain’t always easy, financially speaking. I worked on a pig farm for a year during the onset of covid (in which it was eventually shut down due to pig prices plummeting), so I can speak on a few things.

Sometimes you’ll get a sow who after a 114-day gestation period births 16 piglets. Sounds great. But you have to consider some of the piglets die right away since they are worse than runts and can’t survive a day. So you’re down to 13. Then after detailing (literally cutting the tails off, otherwise piglets at 2 months will begin to bite the others, once there is blood, watch out!) you’ll have to give them proper shots to ensure their survival till market weight. During all this, you better make sure you have farrowing cages, otherwise the sow might accidentally roll over a naive piglet or two while she positions sideways for milking, or even worse yet, she may indulge in infanticide which is common with pigs. It happens even with farrowing cages, but much less so than without them. There will also be piglets that randomly die of unknown causes, so that further complicates things if your looking to profit.

When it comes to breeding, unless you are running a decent operation, keeping a boar around will prove costly for the fees needed, but also the upkeep like shovelling his shit every day or two. Also a boar will lose potency if not bred constantly. One sow every 200 days or so ain’t enough. I would probably just go for AI (artificial insemination) at that point. No boars, no rearing them. Just need fridge space.

Overall I think what you described (raising 5, selling 3 to “eat free”) is probably the best bang for your buck. I’m currently clearing a bunch of land for a terrace to grow some vegetables and friut trees. I might just buy 5 small pigs and let them run around in there and fatten them up. Sounds much better (natural) than actual pig farming lol

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2515083
I’m still very early in the process anon, but I’m basically trying to revive my grandfathers lands, where my family has been for over 100 years. So there’s very much a feeling of being engrained with the land, and wanting to make the best of what I have in order to benefit me, my animals and my family.

We have about 5 acres right beside the house. 2 acres are right up beside the house, we usually just let our horse chill there, but we have partitioned it before to plant sweet potatoes, beans etc with great success due to the sunlight. The rest of the acreage lies below, most of it again is just mostly flat (with some slopes) pasture for the horse/cows, with a random lemon tree in the middle lol.

There is a part (picrel) that lies in a “grota” we call it in Portugal, that is home to about 4 orange trees, a bunch of other fruit trees of the Goyave family, and some wild yams. I’m personally trying to improve things first by cleaning up the entire area. There’s a bunch of weeds, invasive trees, and just general overgrowth that has appeared as the product of neglect. Once that is rectified, I will try to terrace and till some of the parts of the sloped portion. The flat part below will once again see banana trees, as had once been the case. We had to remove them since they are very laborious and need someone there year round to tend to it.

Great thing about where I am is that it’s December 27 and it’s 17 and sunny out, so a perfect time to do all this stuff before planting season, which for my area is February. I have a bunch of other ideas for chickens, pigs and other animals that I may elaborate on later!

I've been researching land prices in my homeland (maine) and it really just hurts my soul. Various things have happened and land prices have skyrocketed. And are continuing to skyrocket! It used to be normal for a person to live in an apartment in southern Maine and work a job to buy some acres of land up north to hunt on. Now the prices are insane and almost no one is selling lots. Corporations are buying huge lots of land and destroying nature to replace it with asphalt and plastic houses that they sell out one at a time. And other corporations are buying the plastic houses and renting them out. Each house on like 0.5 to 0.9 acres of land. I look of various websites and the only few listings that exist for 20 to 50 acres of land are pretty much available only to millionaires.
My soul hurts. My rent keeps going up. I don't know what to do. I just want like 30 or so acres of land to shoot on where I won't bother anyone.

You might get a ton of water running down that slope. You may not need a tank, often a scoop dam will suffice.

Honestly your first move might be getting an earth mover to level the entire plot and put in a dam. You're going to want to remove the grass and either put in beds or mounds so it will drain and not just wash all your fertilizer into the stream.

Looks like you want fruit trees, just bear in mind being in a depression you might get savage winds. Map the wind before plantingb trees or you'll lose all your blossoms year after year.

Jungle and forests with a nearby river, fruit bearing trees, berry producing shrubs, animals that forage off them. Mushrooms if you know what to look for. Could clear out areas to farm, hunting range from small to large game, squirrels to deer etc.

On this I’d bring tools. Saws, axes, traps, knives, fire starters, nails, spear tips, fishing hooks, sewing needles and thread etc. plenty of replaces. There are plenty of traps and tools you could make but they take so much time and effort, not to mention they wear out way quicker.

Honestly though if I had to get dropped off into the wild I’d pack some of the best food and booze around, a laptop with some way to get internet access, and my grandfathers revolver with ammo. If I can’t get rescued I’d party it up then take my life.

Solo survival is not something I can deal with, I tried it for 4 months and was able to make due, could have made it work maybe, but mentally and physically it’s not something I enjoyed. Living by yourself working everyday to survive, it wasn’t sudden but it grinds away at my body and soul until I could either live like a shell of a person or end it.

I'm tired of the industrial grind that is my current work/lifestyle. Naturally, like many other retards, I'm considering moving out onto a hobby farm and giving up on the rest of the world. Please rate this plan, and let me know if there's anything I'm missing. Currently work as a chemist, and am no stranger to working on vehicles as needed.
>Buy ~20 acres for hobby farm
>Plant orchard crops
>mostly looking at cherry, plum, and apple for my part of the US (lean towards dwarf trees)
>Red clover cover crop (n2 fixing, also make some $$ on hay)
>Buy up some instrumentation for soil analysis (expecting around 100k to set up a good lab)
>Run analytical lab as my "full time" job, see if I can't get a deal with the local co-op
I've been pricing it out, and I can get land at around 5-6k/acre tillable and good for fruit trees. I think I'd probably keep working my 9-5 (and paying off the land) until the orchards are ~3-5 years old, where they're producing a decent amount of produce. The area I'm looking at also has several small wineries, which I'd like to negotiate contracts with, meanwhile I'd plan on selling any excess produce at farmers markets. Another idea I was toying with was building an event space barn and renting it out for weddings, festivals, and stuff like that, but I haven't done any real research on the cost to build one of those.

posts.com:
Good thread bros but I feel like some of you guys are making a simple mistake. Being self sufficient doesn't mean having ALL your food and resources come from your property. That's impossible and it never worked like that in any point of human history.
The way they did it and we should do is have a main source of income (e.g. farming crops) and small side farming for your own use (chickens, a couple of cows, pigs, etc). You use your main income to sell and trade locally with your neighbors for whatever you need and the side stuff guarantees a good share of your nutrition.
If you're smart about it you don't even have to have huge land and wait years for your crops to be ready for harvest. For example a small 150 square meter barn can house 1000 laying chickens. They're laying eggs every day and you can butcher the old ones.
Another example is honey bees. It practically doesn't matter the size of your land since bees don't give a fuck about fences and will use all the land they have to feed. I mean of course you'll still make a sizeable initial investment but it may start praying for itself almost instantly.
Yeah it's not epic innawoods off the grid hermit but you get to that point after at least a decade of preppring anyway, so no sense in trying to go directly to that.
Now post homestead channels and waifus.

As long as you have public land or neighboring land that you can access you won't need much. Preferably you would be surrounded by acres of good nut trees, like oaks and hickories that could provide the bulk of your plant calories and also provide lots of hunting opportunities. You would only need a couple acres to act as a home base and also a place you could have more control over the plant life. I'd maintain it to be relatively unforested and have meadows of various staples like wild parsnip and jerusalem artichokes and thickets of fruit like wild plums and apples.

>>2523907
Give yoursef 2 acres of woods for firewood, replant every tree you chip down. Get 2-3 cows, cycle them with either a bull or artificial insemination at different times of year so you get milk year round. You’re gonna want 3 acres of pasture for this. Keep it grass. On your last 2 acres, build your structures and use it for plants that you yourself will consume. Parta that you dont eat can be used to feed poultry or pigs. If I were you, I would buy a piglet every year and raise it for slaughter. You can let it supplement off pine cones or acorns and such in your woods. Take a quarter acre and grow corn to feed the pig. Take another quarter acre and put a pond on it, this is really important because you can periodically excavate the bottom layer of the muck and combine it with compost juice. The water in your pond can also temporarily fertilize your garden or your cow’s pasture. Try and srock your pond with fish that are able to attract and kill and eat insects. Attracting Insects for food should be your pond’s top priority, since insects cone from outside your property, and are thus an infinite source of food. Archerfish are my favorite but I dont think they necessarily breed. You want a fish that breeds more of itself. The fish themselves can be good winter sources of protein and bone nutrients for poultry.

My wife drives to the beach every sunday night and picks up a truckload of seaweed. We use it for poultry feed and compost. If you take an acre or so every couple years and leave it almost fallow, but with a twist: Plant a deep root plant like dandelion and let the roots go deep into the earth. Eventually you’ll want to root up all that dandelion so you can plant grass or some other plant. Well, here’s what happens: the dandelion will grab nutrients that have sunken far into the warth, below where your plants can get at them, and now you will be able to turn those dandelions into fertilizing compost to place back on the topsoil once again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532097
>Permits
You can buy them for $20, buck tags are extra
A cool thing about the PA hunting license is you get year round access to state game land ranges, and you can bring one unlicensed guest. I go to range 203 all the time.
>Guns
Depends on what you are shooting. I use a cheap double barrel sawn down to 20" with target load for squirrels. My typical engagement distance for squirrel is less than 20 feet. If you know somebody that grows fields of feed corn, ask if you can hunt there. In fall/winter the squirrels will come out of the woods to drag cobs back to their trees to eat. Look for where there are more corn cobs and corn scraps out of place in the woods around the bases of trees.

I shoot woodchucks out my bedroom window with a suppressed SBRd AR15 with CMMG 22lr conversion bolt and subsonics. Engagement distance for me is less than 50 feet. Not really "hunting", more like pest control, but I do eat the groundhog that I shoot

30-30 is pretty standard for deer here. This was my first year hunting deer and i didnt get anything but was with people who did. Set up in a stand an hour before sunrise and a couple hours before sunset. If you are with a bunch of other guys you can "drive" the deer in the daytime into eachother. Have one group form a horizontal line each 200+ feet apart and have them walk at least a half mile towards another line of shooters. Wear orange, obviously. Use terrain to your advantage, like pushing deer into a corner like the bends in a river/creek, use the high ground, etc. Also look for where bucks grind their antlers on trees.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Those are lichen. You can see the lecanorine apothecia (the discs) in both photos. Afaik the spores aren't harmful and won't grow in you or anything: being obligate symbiosis, once they reproduce sexually via ascospores, they need to come in contact with the algal partner before they actually do much growing, which means at a minimum they'll need light. People burn wood with (apotheciate) lichen probably way more than they think, they are ubiquitous on many types of hardwood in particular. Source: trust me bro as look into investing in a used Brodo's Lichens of North America if that's where you live, it's expensive but worth it.

>>2523803
I would still get binoculars. Wider field of view, and compact rangefinders have small objective lenses. That means poorer low light performance. That matters if you are in dense woods with lots of shade/shadows, and dusk/dawn. Even binoculars with a small objective lens take that hit. You basically have to compromise in one way or another. These perform very well in low light, but they feel hefty at 1.31lbs(claimed) despite the compact size. Only way you save weight is by going with smaller objective lens, thus making them perform worse in low light.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525329
Reliability, as in the amount of use, banging around. etc they'll withstand before something breaks like the lens seals.

Resolution is a big one. Better bins are better able to resolve small objects. Matters if you are trying to count points on a durr, for example.

Color is more true on better bins, important for bird people.

Generally the mechanics are just nicer. The focus knob stays where you put it, as does the ocular adjustment.

You gotta use the things quite a bit to wring out the differences and that gets more true the more expensive the bins. I've had Swaro ELs and they are great, but I didn't really use them enough to justify the price difference between them and my trusty Zen Ray ED3s. Sold the ELs, they hold their value really well another good point for top end ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532510
The people that need Binoculars watch birds in their yard; drive to nesting spots in open fields/wetlands, or who go to shorelines to watch the seabirds. I've been an avid bird watcher for decades and never take binoculars into the woods with me...because they're pretty useless in the woods. Much of the time you'll only ever hear them but many birds are very curious and will come check you out...they're usually hard to spot because they're stealth as fuck and too fast for binoculars anyways. Ironically some of the best birding areas are near light density urban areas. Depending on where you live Migratory birds can be coaxed into your yard after a year or two of leaving out feed and you really don't have to go to them.
All that said just get a heavy as fuck pair of high power binoculars, some good regional bird books, and accept you're going to spend more time on the trail (in the woods) figuring out the bird songs than ever seeing anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520224
I grew up in a village in germany. Germany is a pretty urban country, and as a result most forests are pretty "tamed". But it was plenty in the eyes of us kids.
Our main motivations were that it was essentially a big playground without supervision. No parents, no strangers, just us. It was possible to play in many ways (play with softair rifles, or dig trenches, or build treehouses, or shelters) that you simply didn't have the space for at home. The biggest draw was the feeling of adventure. We'd climb under the electric fence where sheep were held and pet them (sometimes they'd let us sometimes they'd attack us), then again under it back into the forest, we'd sometimes "steal" honey from some beeskeeper (he knew, but he also knew we wouldn't take much, so he let it happen), we'd search for treasure, go in places that were forbidden (a old mine and a forest bunker were favorites) and sometimes we'd go looking for animals. Always hoping to see deer or a hog, but usually having to settle for some frogs or squirrels instead.
>And also what was the best thing or THINGS you did there?
I have the fondest memories of building shelters. We had "bases" in the forest and inside those we stashed our treasure - stuff we had found. The coolest among those were WW2 leftovers, we had found a ammo box, something that may have been artillery or a mortar round, thankfully not live, and a lot of animal bones. Other than that, fighting with sticks, exploring the mine and the occasional hog encounter.
>>2520359
>at what age would it be safe to turn your kid loose to go play in the woods?
Once they can be trusted to know their boundaries and the risk of the forest around them. It really depends on the forest though. I'd say we were "fake alone" by something like 6 (as in thinking we were alone when parents actually watched/were nearby in emergencies) and really alone around 8.

And don't feel too ashamed of being scared for your kids, it's natural. You seem to do your best to strike a balance by giving them freedom while also offering security with the walkie talkie and stuff. They already have it better than 95% of kids. That fake freedom where you can explore boundaries but know if you fuck up mom and dad can fix it is one of the most magical aspects of childhood.
And in retrospect, us going into the mine and some of the shit we did like playing with the rusted WW2 artillery shell was really unneccesarily risky, wouldn't want my kids to do the same, even if I have fond memories from it kek.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520462
that's the thing though, those close calls we have as kids are actually extremely formative; the tendency towards safety mommyism might actually do more harm than good. i guess it's finding the right balance and praying nothing too catastrophic happens.

where i grew up, we'd often play in the river (hunting snakes/crawdads in the summer). There was a bridge just outside of town with a small dam and sluice box; if the water was high enough we'd jump into the river from the bridge (maybe a 30' fall). Well one summer some kids were jumping off it, but the sluice box was left open. Two kids got sucked in, one drowned and the other became a vegetable for the rest of his life (wound up drowning on his own saliva at the hospital a few years later ironically enough). I think back on how lucky I was to not have that happen. As a parent I wouldn't let my kid jump off that bridge, all the while knowing that my childhood summers would have been worse for such concerns =/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520477
>the tendency towards safety mommyism might actually do more harm than good
I 100% agree with you. Some freedom, and that includes the freedom to fuck up, is needed for kids to become adults. But some risk is also unneeded. Getting hurt playing in the woods and either fixing it with friends together or going back home injured is formative, hitting the rusted WW2 artillery shell with a stone to see what's inside may have ended badly.
I still remember the very first time I went somewhere alone:
I was very young and my parents allowed me to get bread from the bakery alone on a sunday. It involved walking down 3 streets, crossing a small intersection, going into the store, ordering, paying and going back. I couldn't do math yet, so I had no idea how much I had paid or gotten back, but I remember how proud I was when I got back home. Years later I found out I never was alone - my father had followed me with a camera to see if I would cross the intersection carefully, avoid any traffic and be alright on my own. Once he knew I was fine, he knew I could be trusted to leave the house alone from there on.
I think the way they did it was best: First a pilot run, where they kept me safe but I could feel like I was alone. Then once that went well, they let me do my thing. That way they could trust I was fine on my own and I could be free of parental control.
Your main goal is avoiding the shit that can result in death or severe injury, for the rest, it's better if they find out themselves.
We had plenty a injury from homemade fireworks, fighting with sticks, etc. Kids learn surprisingly quickly to take care of each other.
Either way, don't stress about it too much anon, you sound like a great parent. Listen to your inner fears, then rationalize how probable they are. If they are unlikely, allow your kids freedom. If it's reasonable, air on the side of caution. You got this.

I grew up by a forest. I think I walked every path every day every summer from when I was old enough to walk until I had a job in high school.

It was nice. The quiet lets you collect your thoughts, feels good to breathe the air, it was calm with the exception of the occasional other kid or family hiking through.
>the park was preserved by the city, so it didn't shrink, but there's a highway on the north side, high-density housing on the east, and ever increasing intensification on the remaining sides, so it's no longer quiet
It was fun to tell jokes, or stories, or just look for critters. There used to be a lot of raccoons and bats there, but now there's not a lot. Sometimes we'd build little teepees or shelters. But the park staff would yell at us if we got caught, although I suppose there was no real repercussions.
>I walked my parents' dog through the forest a few months ago
>some kids had built a lean-to and were shooting some kind of drug
>I phoned the park building, they seemed annoyed I had bothered

The forest has a lot of hills. If you're not paying attention you can just step off and fall down a 45+ degree incline until a tree stopped you. Well over a decade ago, I remember some friends and I were screwing around, probably just telling jokes and being useless like usual, when one of us tripped and fell down the biggest hill the in the forest. He was just covered in bruises the next day, probably hit every single root and stone on his way down.

Nothing really happened there that was "the best," but I remember loving my walks with my dad. No real events, just wasting time with dad and trying to catch fireflies in the park on the far side of the forest where it opened into a field. Maybe the druggies and dirtbags were always there, but I only remember him explaining things like the pine trees leaking pitch because of the beetles, daring me to climb the trees that mum never would let me, lying to me about how fast a runner I was, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527921
On winter trips, I just dress warm enough such that I can eat snow as I walk. Taking in snow when I'm exerting myself helps keep me cool and prevents me from wasting energy just to warm it up.
Sometimes I'll tie a shemagh around my shoulder like a pouch so I can fit a water bottle inside it. This sits under my fleece, so that my body heat passively melts the snow in the bottle as I hike. With multiple bottles you can trade them out in the shemagh.
When I camp, I store my water upside-down in a snowbank to insulate it. This prevents the cap from freezing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Usual winter is two bottles for me - one standard nalgene and one insulated/vacuum hydroflask type thing. nalgene does most of the heavy lifting for actual drinking while the thermos is there to store water long term for when i need a refill and dont want to unpack the stove and wait for snow to melt.

morning - melt snow (usually not to boiling but warm) fill both and put water treatment in. drink nalgene with breakfast then melt more to refill.

day - drink from nalgene, depeding on day can either keep it in an insulated cozy on my pack or usually just put it inside my jacket where it sits above my backpack belt. if i find convenient open stream refill and purify otherwise go for insulated bottle backup.

evening - get to camp and start melting water. between tent setup and everything refill nalgene and insulated. drink nalgene with supper and then melt a little more for some hot coco. use insulated bottle for night time sipping and when waking up while starting the whole process over.

yes this uses lots of fuel. not boiling and using purifying systems saves you a lot of fuel/time but up to you how warm you want your water. storing bottles upside down doesn't keep them from freezing but usually means the lid getting frozen shut is delayed. eating snow is fine if you are moving but you have to eat a lot and there's bacteria in there that can make you sick.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527921
>In boy scouts the they would always say "be careful turning ice and snow into water, it can use up to much energy if you take it in cold"
>I imagen this also applies to nearly freezing water. But they never explained it past don't eat snow melt it in a cup over the fire.
if i have the time and fuel to i always take it to boiling so it takes longer to freeze again.
>What tips and tricks are used by /out/ to get and keep water below freezing?
only use wide mouth bottles like hdpe nalgenes. you want NO taper at all to the lid.
keep at least 1 water container against your body when traveling if possible. crotch area is ideal.
sleep with your water
OR
boil it in a nalgene before bed and bury it lid down in snow. it will be liquid when you wake up.
>What is the best way to not drop your core temp drinking water in the same time?
in a survival scenario you may have to get pretty sedentary heating snow all day, hoping you get found.
having a highly efficient stove goes a long way. if you haven't considered efficiency with your stoves in the past this is a good reason to with winter stoves.
and bringing a large pot goes a long way. you want a much bigger pot than you typically backpack with. i bring a stanco grease pot in the winter which i consider dead minimum and i would suggest going up to 2x its size.
>>2527922
this, but not always.
first of all it needs to be a wide mouth canteen. not all insulated canteen designs are good.
on short trips an insulated container solves all your problems.
on long trips its not the best solution, i just use normal nalgenes.
you can stretch out its usefulness with a foam or reflectix coozie. worth the weight in the winter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527921
Depends on your water system. While keeping the bottle upside down works well in and around freezing temps, it is not up to the task when it gets much colder. If you are carrying a bottle you can put it in a long and roomy sock, split the upper part of the sock and tie it around your neck, keeping it hanging on chest level beneath your wind stopper/shell layer and on the outside of your wool liner. This is so effective that it can after a long ruck yield lukewarm water, and while you are walking or skiing you can refill the bottle in increments with snow or ice without fear of it freezing allowing you to use less fuel per day. Now bladder systems are also feasible in the winter time, however it is more strenuous to keep warm. Optimally if you can the water bladder should be carried underneath your wind stopper or shell layer, with the tube being routed through the sleeves of your jacket, this will keep it warm and it will never freeze, but it will severely fuck with your ability to wear a backpack. This is the most secure way to carry a water bladder in truly cold weather, i only do this when i use my pulk sled instead of a backpack. Now if you don't have access to a sled, or the terrain/snow cover isn't suitable for one you can also carry water bladders within the backpack, but then it is vital to blow air through the tube after you drink, as the tube is most at risk of freezing while the bladder, if carried against the back of the backpack will most likely not freeze. So be very disciplined with blowing the water back into the bladder each time you take a sip. If you slip up and it freezes you can detach the hose and let it hang down your pants which will fix the issue after some time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Reflectix cover works well for the nalagenes.
A single layer works for around freezing and the double layer one I made works well into the single digits. This allows me to store one and sleep with another in the bag. The outer one is bigger, so while hiking I keep that on the bottle I am not actively drinking out of. Around my area we typically get very dry winters so I don't often have the opportunity for melting snow. I have a larger pot and liquid fuel stove but just haven't gotten many days where that's actually been needed. The biggest change to behavior is therefore just being more cognizant of water sources that run consistently in colder, drier weather. A lot of small mountain streams completely freeze out so I am more prone to mapping out year round sources and carrying extra water. I can expand capacity using the dirty water bag to about 4L total. I have been meaning to make a reflectix sleeve for that bag but even just putting it inside the backpack is usual enough to keep it liquid. Remember to keep your water filters in a warm spot too once they are wet.

posts.com: What are a few survival, bushcraft, outdoorsmanship, and/or backpacking handbooks that are actually good?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532255
https://www.amazon.com/Bushcraft-Advanced-Trapping-Gathering-Cooking/dp/1507206690/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=

This is meant to be pretty good, the guy who wrote it, Dave Canterbury, was on a survival show called Dual Survival, he teaches survival skills. Some people say the books aren't good for more than beginner knowledge, but the book on trapping and skinning is kind of a unique book, not a lot on the subject.

The best survival handbook is the one you write yourself. There is a difference between knowledge and real world application. Sure, you can memorize a book that TELLS you how to do a bowstring fire, but you actually have to practice and get it to work before you can really say you "know how to". Better than books I'd say is just any old youtube video, and then go out in your driveway and try it yourself

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532259
>The best survival handbook is the one you write yourself. There is a difference between knowledge and real world application.
I'm well aware of this. I've been an outdoorsman all my life, was a Cub Scout and Boy Scout, have enjoyed rock climbing, spelunking, hunting and fishing, long-distance backpacking, primitive camping, multi-day paddles down major rivers, etc.

I simply haven't read a manual of this kind since my Boy Scout days, other than fish identification field guides and various fishing books. I might find tidbits of info in some of these books that I don't know myself, wouldn't see on forums or imageboards, etc.

No matter how many decades of experience one has, there's always more to learn. I'm not looking for a beginner's guide, just material to mine for nuggets I may not be familiar with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532330
>>2531884

Main hard skills are probably excel, sql, and a bi tool (power bi, tableau, or looker)
You should also learn some basic domain areas- like a functional area in a company (marketing or finance or hr etc)
So learn some skills, make a portfolio, apply to junior analyst roles.
Lots of kinds of analysts are specialists in domains, ie a finance analyst needs to know more finance stuff. Data analysts tend to know lots of technical data stuff like relational modeling and be conversant in data science concepts. Business analysts do cost benefit analysis on business topics. Lmk if you have more questions

In 1995 I went to the Oregon regional gathering just to see what it was about. I'd been there a couple of hours, talking to the kitchen folks, when I realized I needed something from my car (actually a '71 VW bus that I restored) so off I went. Sitting on the ground about 30 from my bus were three people and a large dog. I walked by the group, smiling and saying hello. The dog jumped to its feet and growled an aggressive and unexpected warning. No worries, I'd been around dogs enough to know they can be a little funny sometimes. I continued on, got what I needed plus a nice nug from my jar to kick down to the group, and walked toward them, I stopped a good ten feet away and said hey y'all, here's a kind nugget for you. The dirtiest of the bunch, an ungrateful bastard of a rapscallion, said, and I quote, "You've got dark energy, man. My dog can sense dark energy."

That was a weird summer. I saw a few Dead shows and saw some shameful shit. "I spent a little time on the mountain, spent a little time on the hill. Things went down we don't understand but I think in time we will."

>>2512781
I spent a couple weeks at the Oregon gathering at the Malheur national forest several years ago. I didn’t fit in, I just went because my hippie friend got married there. But everyone treated my girlfriend and I very nicely. We always had food, weed to smoke, and water. We made a lot of friends, I met some really cool people. Also met some weird people, but the general vibe is very welcoming and positive.

If you’re like me and you don’t identify with hippies, just keep an open mind and definitely be prepared to see some weird shit. But you’re not gonna see orgies in the open or whatever some people think happens there. Just some goofy hippies with their instruments, trinkets, and life stories. In fact, they keep all the alcoholics in their own camp called A camp, steer clear of that, and stay near Jesus Camp and you’re good. Jesus camp is based and they make chocolate chip pancakes every morning for anyone who shows up.

I honestly enjoyed the experience. I might go again some day. It’s cool to be out in a national forest, walking at night using the moonlight to navigate towards the sound of a drum circle, then take some psychs with hippies. If you’re an open minded person, I think it can be fun.

A couple of unique things I remember was Tea Time, a camp serving everyone tea at all hours, and this awesome camp that hauled hundreds of books up the mountain to set up a makeshift library. I chilled and read Walden while relaxing in a meadow one day.

But I’m definitely not the type of person to make it a lifestyle. By the time we left I was ready to go. This was also some years ago, I think 2016 or 2017. So things might have changed and the bad aspects could’ve gotten worse. But if anything it’s nice to be around people actually socializing and meeting each other without any technology for a little bit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Definitely following, ended up with a new bike that is squarely in bike packing/touring territory and I definitely want to get into it.

I am confident in shelter options from my camping kit. I am struggling to figure out food in particular, even with pretty dense foods I feel like I eat a lot more on the bike on longer days. Do people end up carrying way more or limit distance per day so they don't need constant resupply? Tell me your logistic secrets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Been from Lisbon to Barcelona, I can tell you one thing: buy rain shoe covers!!

I still have frozen big toes, almost 2 months after my trek. Shits real. I had a thorn in my big toe all day today and. Didn’t even notice till I got home kek.

Also don’t preoccupy yourselves with exact routes and trying to create a perfect .gpx file on your Garmin. Ain’t happening. Speaking of which, don’t overly rely on automatic route finders either. They will sometimes lead you to impossibly steep roads, or even unmarked shit trails (I’m a tourer). For food, bring dark chocolate, cliff bars, candy, whatever makes you tick. I had the luxury of stopping through towns and cities everyday, so I always had bakeries and grocers at my disposal.

As far as sleep systems, get a 5c quilt and a R value 3.2 pad (I’ve got Nemo tensor) for year-round coverages (minus super cold climates). Try cowboy camping before you decide to take a tent. I was out for a month, ended up only using my 700 gram Lanshan 3 times, the first 3 nights. That worked until Northern Portugal, at which point I opted for albergues. Bring patches for tent/ pad.

There are tons of other things to discuss regarding gear, it’s almost impossible to say within the character limit.

I would just say, be open minded, and don’t be afraid to ask for help. So many kind strangers out there. Also, don’t predicate your success on KMs travelled. In Canada, I could do 300km in one day. My first few days in Portugal, could hardly do 40km, due to the shorter late fall days, set ups, and baggage weight. On my last day, I did 180km from Llieda to Barcelona fully loaded, got a flat and broke a chainring tooth on a national highway (A-2), fun!

You will have stories for the rest of your life, that’s one of the main reasons I undertook such a trip. Lots of fond memories, and you will be ever thankful for everyday things, like hot showers, a warm bed with clean sheets, fridges, microwaves and cupboards of food. GL anons

>>2529803
Are you in the UK? Hostel option I mentioned is a good workaround from being completely homeless. Work is usually easy and involves sitting around a lot. There's loads of opportunities to get laid if you're decent looking and can LARP as some cool traveller guy. Just don't make it obvious you're a bum, most hostels don't want anything to do with that sort as they're largely scumbags and retards. You get a place to stay without needing contracts, deposits or any other nonsense. In UK you can definitely use a letter from hostel manager as proof of address... or just have something shipped to you, like a SIM card. You get access to kitchen so you can save what you got by actually being able to eat decent, home cooked meals, plus you always got a table and a chair. You don't need any workarounds for showers, etc. There's typically a storage lockers in dormitories, so you can lock your essentials up. In two years working for three different hostels I saw something being stolen twice, one time the thief being caught within 15 mins. Other time someone jacked a pair of useless headphones, which I guess was plain bad luck. Don't look seedy. Have a good relationships with other staff and whoever runs the place.

Being full on homeless in UK is fucking retarded and lame. Constant rain and moisture, everything is mostly industrialized, country side is all farms and they've got even less tolerance for bums than cities, and almost all homeless are schizophrenics or junkies.

If you need some income you can just pick up a dishwasher job for a few weeks and then drop it. They pay weekly, so as soon as the cash goes into your account just don't show up.

Post your favorite /out/ related books, weather it be a informational book on a certain skill, autobiography type book, or even fiction.

Picrel is a very good book, it is about a guy who grew up poor and had to hunt in order to feed himself and his family. He uses some very interesting but extremely effective hunting/trapping methods and techniques, and although it may seem like you are just reading a story you will realize you are actually learning a lot about hunting from his anecdotes and experiences, weather it be inside or outside of the law. He doesnt waste time on meaningless details, but goes into good detail about his techniques, he is a old guy who uses some fudd guns but the methods still apply with any nicer gear you may have. If you hunt you will want to read this, there is also a part II if you like the first one, but I just went ahead and ordered both at the same time.

>>2529202
Walden makes this list. David Quamman is a good author but, again, not sure the theme of this list---certainly not outdoors. Have you even read any of Charles Darwin? Lmao

Surprised they have to be mentioned, but the best naturalists/travel authors I've come across are as follows
>Henry David Thoreau, e.g. Walden, Maine Woods, etc.
>John Muir's writings
>Any of Jack London's tales of the Klondike
>Aldo Leopold
>Knut Husman's Growth of the Soil

John Rowlands' Cache Lake Country is spectacular as well. It is a month-by-month breakdown of life in the Canadian wilderness with an Indian chief and a nature illustrator. Throughout the text, Rowlands offers tips and advice on everything from rice pudding to homemade refrigerators to animal tracking.

All of these suggestions fall under various themes of nature apprecuation, self sufficiency, and living off the land. They are cozy reads, but your experience may vary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530284
forced patina is what you want, like anon said.
and like anon said all you have to do is expose the knife to something acidic for a while.
how i personally prefer to do the acid etching depends on how i plan to use the knife. really thick patinas last a long time between re-applications but give the metal a sort of matte texture which drags on food.
knives that might contact food: i just stab a banana or apple or something and leave it for a day.
knives that will not contact food: near-boiling apple cider vinegar for a few mins, or cold apple cider vinegar overnight. cheap household product you might have around already that gives near-black super thick patinas that last forever. the patina sheds a bit at first but it goes away, rub it down real good.
people make it more complicated than it is that's all you really need to know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
the exact materials i used as examples can be swapped out for anything with vaguely the same ph.
and if you do a thick ass patina then decide you want to use the knife to process food, the matte texture etched into the metal eventually wears off its not permanent.

>>2530494
>Even the sheath is good for just hanging off whatever your wearing.
>mora sheath
everyone either loves or hates the modern mora sheaths. they're really polarizing for a sheath.
the little plastic tab hanging off of it is meant so that you can daisy chain multiple knives to each other. its actually a really cool idea/feature but if you don't ever plan on using it the sheath can be significantly improved by grinding or cutting it off the sheath because it really likes to catch on clothes.
the classic mora sheaths are DOODY BUTT ASS. they're trash but that was always the case with classic moras.

i think even if you hate the mora sheath like some people, its super worth it to get a custom kydex or leather sheath made for one. seems silly to spend $30-50 on a $10-20 knife but if you think about it, its still an incredibly competitive knife at $50-70 and once you buy the sheath you can replace the knife that goes in it unlimited times forever for pennies if you ever lose or fuck it up.
i cant think of any better beater knife than a mora with a custom sheath desu.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm from southern Appalachia, but I generally only carry firearms into the woods if it's muzzleloader or rifle season and I'll be within reasonable distance of a road, just in case a whitetail steps over a ridgeline. It happens. I've never seen any point in carrying a pistol, because the odds of needing to shoot a human being are lower than winning the Mega Millions (and everyone assumes everyone else is armed, anyway); the only realistic probability of an animal attacking a grown man in these parts is the classic stumbling between a black bear and its cubs scenario. Climbing into my car to drive to the nearest town is at least 100x riskier than going into the woods unstrapped. If we start to develop a noticeable feral hog problem or something along those lines, I might change my mind.

I do keep at least a pistol in my vehicle and sometimes on my person whenever I'm traveling to a city with >100,000k population, because that's where you're far more likely to run into dangerous animals. It ain't the woods, that's for sure.

As for improvised weapons that are actually tools and not proper weapons (despite what Airstrip One citizens seem to believe), I always carry a folding knife, optionally a skinning knife or boning knife, and I may carry the very same Estwing hatchet (which is top-tier) shown in the OP's pic when hiking/camping.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526996
I don't have any pictures of my encounters because I'm more concerned with reading the situation than recording it.
But i'll tell you this: Bears and other high mammals are a lot like people. Strong, furry, powerful people. They have emotions, they have egos. They usually want nothing to do with me, as >>2526999 said. But because they have egos, they respond to wounds to their pride.
For example: I was walking down a tundra hillside, when above me a brown bear was walking sideways to me about 200 meters away. He knew I was there but absolutely did not care. I just talked to myself at a normal volume and he kept walking away.
On the other hand, I was with a group of 3 and we were walking along another tundra hillside. We saw a black bear below us. We immediately began yelling and making noise to scare it away. This time, the thing developed a keen interest in us. It stayed in the valley for the entire day.
That showed me that bears respond badly to perceived challenges, just like people. You should only start making noise/freaking out once the bear shows interest in you. Otherwise, just speak in a normal tone and give the thing some space.
>>2527977
In my experience, I've had worse experiences with black than brown bears. Maybe this is only where their ranges overlap, but my theory is that blacks get picked on constantly by the big guys. So they are more aggressive towards weaker bears and people in turn. Whereas the big guys only get into scraps if its necessary to defend their territory or cubs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What are the actual benefits of a hammock over an ultralight tent?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529428
>comfort
This is an obvious one. No matter how thick your pad is, it will never be as comfy as an appropriately sized and correctly hung hammock.

>ventilation/condensation
It’s a major issue in the south east, and hammocks are the most ventilated shelter option. The comparison to single wall tents isn’t even close.

>site selection is easier
On a macro scale, you can choose a general area and be guaranteed to find at least an ok hammock spot (if you’re in a forest, obviously). Generally that’s done to be on the leeward side of a hill, or further from a water source, or in a less-traveled area. In a micro sense, there are fewer worries about rocks, sticks, vegetation, or roots. A slight angle to the ground doesn’t matter. Puddles aren’t a major concern. You’ll never set up only to realize there’s a weird lump under your hip.

>slight versatility
I can keep my tarp in it’s skins if I’m certain there won’t be any rain, pull back just half of it for privacy, leave up one side in “porch mode,” or really hunker down in storm mode. A single walled tent is set up one way.

>utility
A hammock tarp is fairly large, providing much more useable space if there’s rain. It’s only a slight advantage, as most decent tents already have enough space under the vestibule. A hammock also doubles as a chair, but it’s not like you can just plop it down wherever (but it’s still a place to sit).

>not stuck in a dog house while it’s raining
Self explanatory. I’ll be in a hammock, sitting sideways, swaying lightly with my hammock in porch mode while I listen to the rain pattering lightly against my tarp. Peak comfy.

>cooler, as in less hot
This really only applies to the Deep South, where summer nighttime temps can make sleeping in a tent much less enjoyable. The convective heat loss in a hammock is a net positive.

>great for old people
Old folks have trouble sleeping on really hard surfaces, and we won’t be “young” forever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529407
>trend
Trends don’t fade away. I think you meant “fad,” but were inadvertently correct; people switching to hammocks from tents is indeed a trend.

It’s hard to say when it started, but it was definitely more than 10 years ago. I know Dutch (from Dutchware) hiked the AT with a hammock in 2003, and it was a sort of novelty at the time. But his company has been around probably since 2008, and he started selling hammock bodies in 2011 or 2012 (I still have a netless Poly-D).

The reason it even became a thing is because of the internet. For a large part of the US, a hammock has a lot of benefits. But tents are ubiquitous. People didn’t really think to use a hammock until they saw other people doing it online.

It’s not going to just fade away, but it won’t completely replace tents either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529460
Since everyone is tossing their own spin on this
>Comfort
Honestly a matter of the person but at least personally this is why I choose hammock as my primary. I am often rolling around in bed over the course of the night, between the cocoon factor and generally being more tired after hiking I rarely move in the hammock.
>Ventilation
I will actually give this to all forms of tarp camping. Although there's a skill and variability to it being able to adjust how close the tarp is to the ground, how closed off it is, etc. really allows you to dial it in. In the
>Cooler
factor as well, you can get more air flow or with a large enough tarp can create a really nice wind shield.
>Versatility
As above, can definitely tailor the shelter a bit more. Not as much as tarp only but close.
>Site selection
I will give this a yes but it is dependent on your area. If you camp more desert, rocky alpine, meadowlands you may have more issues finding appropriate hang spots.
>Rain
On one hand I've had gear get a little damp with splash, but on the other I have slept through inches of rain without a bother.

I will give tents credit in that the lack of flexibility is sometimes a boon. It only goes up one way and if you're comfy on the ground it's a lot more 'brain off do camp task' after a long day. It took many trips to dial in my hammock camping to a point where it is both fast and consistent.

Most good hammocks come with an attached bugnet. They zip on to one edge of the hammock, and are suspended above you by the hammocks structural ridge line. When not in use they can be bundled up and tied in neatly to the sewn edge. Some can zip completely off, but that’s not very common. Mosquitoes can easily bite through a hammock but not though an underquilt.

Another option is a full coverage net like the one in this pic I’ve posted a few dozen times. It’s several ounces heavier than a zip on net but can be used in the warmer months without an underquilt. Most have poorly designed, oddly shaped zippers, so you really have to shop around for one.

The great majority of preppers aren't survivalists or snake eaters, they aren't marksmen, they have little to no access to anything beyond basic resources, their practical knowledge (of weather, terrain, navigation, trapping, hunting, fishing, mechanics, electrics, engines, anatomy, etc.) Is minimal to nonexistent, they've never been out on more than a dayhike or weekend excursion in developed territory, and their physical fitness ranges from laughable to adequate, with some rare cases making par.

Without quite realizing it, they are extremely dependent on some combination of electricity, gas, municipal water, shipping and courier services, and, of course, their vehicles.

As such, prepping disaster supplies and materiel for a week or two, or a month at most, is prudent. Preparing for the apocalypse is a waste of time and a LARP. You as an individual will never have the knowledge, skills, or resources to adequately bunker up in any workable way, unless you're rich enough to buy land, materials, and hire a bunch of people (in which case it's not just you, an individual, preparing yourself for the apocalypse).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2520766
I'd agree with this. Efforts should go into the most likely scenario first. And for most of us, that usually means preparing for long term unemployment. Do you have an emergency fund? Have you paid off any high-interest debt? Do you have an income stream outside of your job? Do you know roughly how much you spend each month? Do you make regular efforts towards reducing that number?

Another important facet is just general health. Do you smoke? Drink heavily/regularly? Do you exercise regularly? What's your diet like? How's your stress level? Taking care of yourself is enormously underrated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521355
>Another important facet is just general health. Do you smoke? Drink heavily/regularly? Do you exercise regularly? What's your diet like? How's your stress level? Taking care of yourself is enormously underrated.
This. Also, if you have any outstanding physical problems (e.g. carpel tunnel, bad knee or shoulder, etc.) consider getting it fixed now. Any sort of physical ailment or disability will be a huge liability in a survival situation where you may not have access to advanced medical care for months.

I think the concept of 'prepping' has been taken to mean schizo nutjobs bs on the TV shows that put hundreds of pounds of rice into home depot buckets and let it go bad over the years. The popularization of that concept has also lead to consumer preppers who are using their interest/hobby in prepping as a subconscious excuse to allow themselves to buy a bunch of crap they don't actually need. You can see the same cope drive in many of the reddit-tier "hobbies" like mechanical keyboards or headphones or chefs knives. You need only one of any of these things but the 'hobbiest' will always obtain a silly amount to justify his preferences and engagement with the 'hobby'. I think this is the rationale most preppers have. It's a fun thing to read about for a week and it's easy to convince yourself you _need_ a fancy new flashlight that you didn't know existed yesterday. And if I'm buying it to protect my loved ones it has to be a good decision right?
Preparedness as a general concept is a separate thing from this new reddit prepping hobby. They started out the same of course. Learning how to garden, preserving food, self-sufficiency. Those are boring thing and hobbies in themselves. It's hard to turn "leave some meat in some salt for a few months" into a consumer frenzy so it gets less excited evangelist noobies and as such it gets easily eclipsed by the new reddit prepping hobby.

The best preparation one can do for a potential collapse is learning how to live independently. If shit ever did hit the fan, your knowledge would allow you to head straight to the forest and still live, whereas useless people would do as they've always done which is rely on others, they'd raid shops and huddle in their towns & cities.

The chance that'll actually happen is probably slim, but it's still significant enough that it's worth picking up survival and outdoorsman skills for that reason alone. It could be a solar flare destroying nearly all the world's electronics, nuclear war taking out the superpowers and halting intl. trade, etc.

The pursuit of the outdoors not only gives mental health benefits and something fun to do, but also gradually the skills and tools to survive independently. Fuck anyone who'd give up the second shit hits the fan.

You're right. I've got a plan, and an off-grid family farm in a an area that's low population density and produces a wide range of foods.

The first year or two would be fine. But then machinery would start to break, the bore would silt up making irrigation hard, electric pumps might start to break, fertilizer and fuel would dry up and everything would start to become much more manual and labor intensive.

Survival would still be fine with sharing and barter, but it wouldn't be too many years before I fuck up my last pair of glasses, get an infection, or have a bad tooth. There are paramedics around but doctors would be impractically far away in any emergency. A bushfire would roll through after a few years and with nobody to fight it, it'll be down to luck and how good we were at prevention

I'd give it a red hot go but realistically, I'd be dead in 5-10 years even if it went great. It's a way to get through short term disruption.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You should really consider your potential "mission".
Bug out bags were all the rage, but for many it really doesnt make sense, hunkering down with supplies is much more prudent. Also consider something like a get home bag, i for example spend my weeks in a large university town, that is prone to floods and has a large population of "urban youths". I go there by train and sleep there during the week, so i have setup a backpack with everything needet to hike the 80 miles back to the small town i come from, where i have family, friends and the community to fall back on.
This includes shelter to spend one or two nights, food, water, medical, tools, warm clothes etc.
The same thing could also be in your car, incase you brake down, there is no more gas available or all roads are blocked and it will bring you the last 100miles back home if need be.
Things like power outages, natural disasters, civil unrest, and supply shortages are very real and often dont involve going innawoods or platoon size assaults against fortified targets with your friends.

Couple things:
>All memes aside there really are some things hanging over society's head that could cause a catastrophe. It's happened plenty of times in history. Modern society relies on really brittle supply chains, even COVID caused a ton of disruption and that was like the common cold compared to some shit humanity has had to deal with in the past. Another Great Depression might be around the corner, the US economic system is a giant house of cards built on unsustainable debt. And there's the usual yellowstone, nukes etc as well.
>Prepping is cumulative. If you're prepared for a total SHTF, you'll handle more run of the mill emergencies like natural disasters and power outages, crime and riots and recessions/depressions really well.
>It is based on a mindset of self-reliance that benefits you in lots of other ways. It encourages you to build skills, prepping is part of why I learned to do my own home and mechanical repair work instead of paying someone else. You train to fix your car so you can drive away from the zombies, then you apply the knowledge to save you a few hundred bucks when you need a brake caliper done.

This all assumes sensible, rational prepping aka building redundancy and self-reliance into your life and preparing for society and infrastructure to not be there to help you anymore. Yes, guns and ammo are a part of that but only a small part. If your prepping solely consists of buying 50 ARs and a million rounds of ammo you're a fucking laughingstock to the rational prepper community.
