posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: SHTF/Crisis: Kerosene as a fuel for cooking stoves?
posts.com:
Anons, what are your thoughts on stockpiling kerosene as a fuel for cooking/boiling water (versus other hydrocarbon fuel types, alcohol, etc)? From what I've read so far propane seems like a pain what with the bulky cylinders, and gasoline is apparently shit for long-term storage.

In a bona fide SHTF situation, I would obviously have to eventually switch to wood, so the kerosene would be to tide me over until any wood I've gathered/harvested would be dry enough to burn easily.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532102
You need a supply of wicks for whatever appliance(s) you intend to use. They need frequent maintenance. My wick heaters and cooker need trimming about every other fill-up.
The Coleman stoves (multifuel) do not care, but at "simmer" it can soot pans.

Also Kerosene can "sour" if stored improperly. Most simple appliances won't care, but some of the more sophisticated cat/wick heaters will not run well on it. You want to keep as much air away from the fuel as possible.

Now, you can use Jet-A as a direct substitute, and it is usually much cheaper than the gallon jugs of K1 one commonly finds in hardware stores.

I have ~40 gallons in 5 gallon cans, and am looking at filling a 55 gallon drum with Jet-A for use as fuel during the infrequent, but often lengthy power outages I see, and for use in my camping stoves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2532102
Propane lasts until the rust pierces the container. That could be 50+ years. Downsides are awkward storage size and poor cold weather performance. The best indoor fuel.

Alcohol will always find a way to evaporate away once opened, but it burns clean. Fine for indoors, but colder flame.

Naphtha/kerosene are a good middle ground between the above, but I don't like the fumes. I have a can of half use napatha that is over a decade old and still burns in my coleman dual fuel. I don't recommend indoor use.

Wood is the ultimate solution, but they're by far the most expensive when you count the cost of a stove. If you're okay with doing things outdoor from square one, you might consider just building a metal firepit with a grill and stock some dry wood.

If you're somewhere really sunny, solar ovens are also an okay option to research.

Keep in mind that outdoor cooking smells will bring people from miles around in times of famine. Only use outdoor cook pits for boiling water if its a legit SHTF event.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Anon who spends a lot of time in the jungle here. The priority is protection from bites/stings/shit that can cut you, so:

>Normal everyday use in jungle environments
Hiking shoes/hunting boots

>Snake country or stepping off trails
Snake boots/leather gaiters

>Actually walking into water below knee / waterlogged mud
Indestructible $30 rubber boots as tall as you can get them

>Crossing rivers too deep
Sandals. Stash boots into drybag then switch after crossing.

Some locals just use sandals, but they are just playing a probability game where the logic is "A snake has never bitten me in my life so I'll probably be fine". If you think like that then yeah, get some good sandals and call it a day.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: How long could you last innawoods if society collapsed whilst you were camping?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2525955
best almost everywhere: merino wool nylon blend
best in hot+humid weather (florida etc): thin coolmax synthetic
really fucking rainy places (pnw etc): thick coolmax synthetic

avoid 100% wool imo. the lifespan is too short and its wasteful. when you blow holes in 100% wool socks they're done for, whereas with nylon blend ones you'll still have the nylon mesh the wool's attached to in tact to hike out on until you can replace them.
consider stronger mixed natural fiber blend socks if you're one of the anons who doesn't like synthetic fibers and want to fully avoid them.
wool alternatives: alpaca (hypoallergenic, non itchy, bit less durable) bison down (more durable + better thermal properties) muskox (similar durability, best thermal properties) and angora (best-best thermal properties but can only be blended in small %s because fiber is very short)

posts.name: Umbrellanon
posts.com:
>>2527985
My man!

Short answer: yes.

But! Umbrellas are very situationally dependent. Sometimes they’re absolutely the best option, and sometimes there are better options out there. If there’s a lot of wind driven rain (and I mean a lot, not just a slight breeze in a light drizzle), you might be better off with a jacket. If the trail is really over grown (basically bushwhacking; a little overgrowth won’t hurt anything), then your umbrella may get snagged too often.

Where they work well is light to moderate rain. Just as a rain jacket is paired with pants, an umbrella can do the same. They also pair well with a very light jacket, such as a water resistant running jacket. That combo provides heavy protection from rain via the umbrella while the jacket keeps any blowback from soaking you, and it’s still more breathable than most options. A lot of thruhikers are using this combo now. It’s pretty versatile; if it’s not raining too hard you leave the jacket off and use just the umbrella (unlike just a rain jacket, where it’s all or nothing).

Breathability is a huge umbrella advantage. It’s why it’s the absolute best rain protection in hot environments during rainy summers. In the South, rain showers spring up out of nowhere, and dissipate just as quickly. They’re so scattered that raining while the sun is out is fairly common. A jacket would leave you very hot and sweaty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530344
for winter it's not that uncommon to layer two bags/quilts and works pretty well. you lose out a bit in weight but in some cases it works better than a single bag as you can adjust for temp swings and layering a down inside a synthetic can help with frost forming inside the insulation.

https://support.enlightenedequipment.com/hc/en-us/articles/115002770588-How-to-layer-quilts-for-sub-zero-camping

Is it still /out/ if I can get food and shelter from convincing strangers to let me sleep in their house and eat their food for a night?
It's still be doing 25+ Mile hikes through wilderness by compass through whatever nature throws at me but when there's so much private property and available food it feels as though doing otherwise is trying to maintain a dead tradition rather than focus on what's really important like going out and touching grass.
The historical document the Red book of Westmarch recovered by anthropologist and philology Professor John Ronald Reuel Tolkien depicts a story where people thousands of years ago walked like 2,000 miles (some barefoot, one morbidly obese, another very old) and it was nearly all through nature but the people still stayed at people's houses and ate people's food along the way. That historical account feels more real than the self imposed survivalism stuff I see a lot here.

>Is it still /out/ if I can get food and shelter from convincing strangers to let me sleep in their house and eat their food for a night?
It doesn't have to be a months-long expedition to qualify as /out/. Even day hikes qualify as /out/. The conflicts on /out/ arise when casuals start to delude themselves that they're more experienced than they really are, that the scope of what they do outdoors is wider than it really is, or that they're experts in some aspect of outdoorsmanship when they clearly aren't.

The vast majority of arguing on /out/ is between a bunch of casuals, none of whom are experts. It's obvious and it's why I love the board, pure entertainment. That said, experts often disagree with each other as well.

"Trail angel" is a common term for people who help out hikers, up to and including providing a meal, shower, and possibly a bed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527960
most anons dont live in areas with many types of dangerous snakes, plus most people use established trails where its even less likely to encounter a snake. typically they will try to avoid you (some rattle). if there a real concern as this anon >>2527964 mentioned, there are boots specifically made for bites though it seems overkill if you arent working in an area with a large density. if its more of a fear, then best way i found is to learn as much as you can, so find out all the types around the area you are, what they look like, how they behave, where they show up, how to deal with them etc. but dont let that stop you anon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531789
cant help you with deer but hunting small game with no prior knowledge or help is much easier. for me it just involved getting a hunting and firearm license which was a couple of courses and a test. then picking up a cheap .22 (10/22 is popular) and practicing with it. then looking for areas i could go and the type of game there then researching online their behaviours, skinning, tracking, etc. then wait for season, drive out there and give it a shot, odds are first few times will be pretty bad but still fun as i like to wander through forests. i imagine deer and large game is a lot more involved for gear and hauling especially alone

posts.com:
My Renegade GTX finally broke after 3 years of heavy everyday use and sporadic hiking.
The leather separated at the pictured spot, it looks as if it was cut along the edge of the sole but the membrane seems intact. As it is out of warranty it would be expensive to have it repaired by Lowa considering I got it for a 50% discount, so I am looking to get a new pair of shoes/boots

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You can't repair injected sole boots. They're toast unless it's a simple hardware issue or something on the cuff. Lowa only does rebuilds on cemented sole boots, like the Tibet.

If you got 3 years out of those Renegades, I'd just stick with those. You know the fit, and the quality.

Other good brands from Europe are Hanwag, Zamberlan. I've had lots of Lowas and a few Zamberlans, just got my first pair of Hanwag (ferrata). Reminds me of the Lowa Tibets I had.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Thick wool/merino socks and winter boots.

>sweating the whole time
That's not good. Sweat makes your clothes wet which we'll eventually make you cold. It's dangerous to get wet.
If your body temp is too high your feet will also sweat, which will make your feet cold.
You need to prevent yourself from an sweating. Remove layers and only put them back on if the temprature drops or when you stop.
This is why layering is important.
It's also why you should avoid wearing cotton (especially as a base layer), cotton loses all it's insulating properties when wet. Wool on the other will keep you warm even when wet (within reason).
As will synthetics. These materials when worn as baselayer will also whick sweat away from your body and prevent persperation build up.
This is why merino is so popular(and expensive).

Tl;dr Get better boots and thick merino socks. Wear synthetic or merino baselayer and midlayers.
If you're too warm, remove layers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531775
>my toes remained numb for weeks and haven’t recovered.
They likely won't. You've most probably killed off some of your capillaries and lost some nerve tissue; other tissues that were fed by those capillaries may be similarly affected. There's a possibility of dry gangrene.

With some portion of your toes' capillaries no longer providing blood (and warmth), you are even more susceptible to cold and frostbite than before.

The correct thing to do is to see a physician ASAP and stop going out in the cold immediately. I'm afraid this isn't like everyday cuts, bruises, and bumps that go away on their own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: An abridged version of the journals and reports written by Samuel Hearne, the first whitey to reach the Arctic Ocean in North America by land in the 1790's. Took him a couple tries and a couple years. Lived and travelled with Aboriginals the whole time and talks about their culture, cuisine, temperaments, the land and climate, etc. Talks about how they cook and eat Caribou stomachs along with all the moss and berries inside, the genocidal hatred of a tribe he travelled with and how they went about killing a group of Inuit, talks about making canoes and snowshoes, the fur trade, hunting moose and deer (moose just let you kill them if they're swimming but deer thrash about and can break your canoe/kayak), the kind of deadly conditions people had to deal with, etc. One time they got stuck on a hill under a nearly sub-zero rain and howling wind for several days, without being able to pitch their tents or cook food because of the wind and couldn't leave the hill because they were staying out of reach of a flood surrounding them. Surprisingly it doesn't seem like anyone got too sick, meanwhile our 21st century asses would probably die.

America is going that way too, we just have the advantage of being much younger than them, and having far more territory. But the same thing is happening. More and more ground being civilized, either for resource extraction, grazing land extension, or for easily accessible camping grounds.

For wilderness camping, the US (and Canada, and Russia) have a huge advantage, but we shouldn't take it for granted. Europe used to have wilderness too, and wild predators, but they settled all those lands. Same shit is happening in US. Though maybe we skipped the worst by learning from their mistakes, for example, wolves are being reintroduced into some areas.

It's a big political issue, where I live. Not much farming, mostly ranchers. Wolves kill cows, obviously. So you've got the scientific environmentalists, wolves control grazer population which reduces erosion and is better for the ecosystem overall, vs ranchers who are losing money from cattle deaths, plus people's who are afraid of wolves.

It's a very messy subject. That said, I support the wolves. there will be losses, but it's best for everyone in the long term.

Same with places like Germany where they caught that black forest rambo in 5 days (actually impressive 2bh) and were able to get hundreds of cops and FLIR choppers into the area basically immediately. Real wilderness is difficult to access and a lot easier to hide out in. US designated wilderness is typically not allowed road constructions or structures at all and is often on mountainous forested terrain with a harsh climate and can be up to 30 air miles from the nearest town of any size and over 50 to a town of 1k even in the lower 48 (and several non wilderness spots in the lower 48 are over 100 miles to the nearest town of any size). National forests will typically have plenty of forest roads, but have a larger area than wilderness zones and can have equally harsh climate and terrain. Most outdoorsmen haven't actually camped out in designated wilderness. For the UK I bet the closest they can get to US level is Iceland and Norway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527900
It's a combination of cleaner water and resistance to the local microbiota of the water.
Hunter-gatherers and early farmers/pastoralists benefited from low population density. Water-born pathogens from human shit weren't nearly as common as today.
Also, people can gradually develop resistance to the bacteria in the water around their home. I saw this in Cameroon; people who travelled to different areas for a short time would bring water with them to avoid diarrhea as an "allergic" reaction. I've also heard of Mexicans getting diarrhea when they come to the U.S. for the same reason, despite our cleaner water.

>>2519786
Muck boots fall apart in less than a year. Sole rips off because of bad glue. Get ones without a separate sole. Lacrosse grange are good. Whether you get those or another brand, still be really careful about puncturing them through sticks. All mud boots puncture really easily. You can use sealant glue made for wetsuits to seal holes in rubber or neoprene boots

posts.com:
These are mine.

From left to right they are, cherry, Diamondback willow, dogwood, Oak and the longest one is juniper.

The oak one was grown by my mother who planted an acorn from the sacred oak tree from the Cossacks.

The Diamondback willow, second from the left, grossing Alberta and I got this at a charity sale for 20 bucks. I've always wanted one but none grows where I live.

The Twisted one in the middle is Western dogwood and the twist in it was from honeysuckle growing around it. I walked past this branch for years before I harvested it waiting for it to get big enough.

On the far right is the Juniper which I got from Smuggler's Cove. I use that for my most intense hikes.

posts.com:
I'll never understand mountaineering. On an intellectual level, I comprehend wanting to summit a peak "because it's there," even though most been already been summited by many others in previous decades. I realize that charting a new route to climb, achieving something a little better or faster than most, or just reaching personal goals can provide motivation.

It's just that tall mountains aren't the only things that are "out there." There are a lot of other things "out there" and, in my view, most of those things seem much more interesting than going up and down various large, lifeless rocks featuring only smaller chunks of themselves, ice, and snowpack.

Take SCUBA, for example. There are fish, molluscs, crustaceans, and reefs and shit to explore, and studying oceanic biomes can be useful, even profitable. If mountaineers were chipping out fossils then that might be slightly interesting, but that would probably ruin the precious routes used by mountaineers to go up big rock and down again.

In some ways this argument can apply to most /out/ activities to some extent. For example, non-fishermen believe fishing is boring and that all you do is sit motionless holding a pole, which isn't true at all in practice. At least with fishing, though, you might see a turtle, you'll spot some interesting birds, there are trees, you'll get to talk to other fishermen, you might get lucky and find a nice lost lure, you can have fun paddling a boat around... mountaineering is just rocks, snow, and the company only of other mountaineers.

I do respect it, because of the expertise and skill needed. I know you derive great enjoyment from it. But then, a severely autistic person derives great enjoyment from stacking his anime plushies in a highly specific way, and it may even require great concentration and skill to pull off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2528632
You're on to something with the fishing comparison. It's not "just" snow and rocks and ice. When climbing up a mountain you absolute do see lots of animals. On one day on Mt. Rainier I saw chipmunks, grouse, pipits, marmots, squirrels, mountain goats - the mountains are very much alive. You are also actively and physically exploring, even if it's in a different way from how you would explore a forest or a reef. Strange ice formations, interesting rocks, alien and exciting escarpments, and of course the majesty of the mountain itself. Finally the change in view as you ascend is extremely rewarding just from the beauty of it. I guess it's impossible in some sense to explain an interest to someone who doesn't enjoy the same things you do unfortunately but my answer to "why not explore a more vibrant biome like a coral reef" is, why not both? Every part of nature has something of its own to enjoy beyond simply being there.

posts.com:
This photo always brings back a terrible memory I have. I haven't ever told anyone but my family this story but here goes.

A decade ago while solo hiking in snow for the first time (blue mountains australia) I fucked up stepped into a pile of snow which I thought was solid and slipped down a slope ending up in an ice stream in full gear, maybe a 40lb pack on. I went in head first straight under. The stream was only 3 foot wide but it was a 3 foot drop to actually get into it. I didn't even know it was there and only slid 20m to get into it, it was hidden by its snow capped edges. I quickly threw my body around and when my feet couldn't touch the bottom I started to panic. It was moving fast and I was immediately carried away, it felt like I was in that stream for 2 minutes but I think it was only 10 seconds. Some how I managed to drop my pack and kick up off something back onto the edge and dragged myself back up. After I got out I tore all of my clothes off to my underwear, which took all of my energy
and ran for the road which was about 1km away and I was very lucky that there were cars there with people pulled over having snow ball fights with their children. So I came bolting over in my underwear and the people had seen what happened to me got me in their car and wedged me between two adult men in the backseat. I remember sitting there and I felt so pleasant and at peace with everything, kind of zoning in and out of the pleasant feelings, then back into the reality that I was almost naked between two men who were rubbing my body and sandwiching me. I lost like 2k worth of gear and have never been back snow hiking.

I agree to an extent. Becoming a 46er doesn't make you special because nearly 14,000 people have done it. It does have some good scrambles though and exposes you to different weather and trail conditions. Many serious mountaineers cut their teeth on 4-6k peaks in the Adirondacks and New England before moving on to bigger climbs out west and internationally. It's a good place to train if you live in the northeastern part of the country, esp in winter.
I'm also glad that the High Peaks serve as a containment zone for normies because it leaves most of the ADK's 6M acres free of crowds. I've had complete solitude in some really scenic areas of the park, even at the peak of fall foliage, because most people were concentrated on the highly-trafficked trails.

I've been in better spots for sure. Grew up in Washington state (age 7 to 18), and I genuinely believe that the "vibe" over there is better. I wasn't even in the hyper-hipster libtard areas like Seattle, I was inland, right by Idaho. I think part of it just has to do with the local environment. Southern Ontario is crowded, highly industrial (aka ugly in lots of parts), very car-dependent (with bad road infrastructure), sub-par access to natural areas. Washington has insane access to a huge variety of great outdoors stuff as long as you aren't in the central area (even so, its like 1.5-2hr to pristine mountains), less crowded, nicer neighborhood (not as much of the expansive cheap suburbs we have here).

I think about moving every week. My job sucks and makes me want to blow my brains out, but I'm paid better than most people of my age with my educational background. Also gf has a job she likes here. So I'm here for now, but I would move within the week if my gf quit her job or we broke up.

I strongly believe that some places are better than others. I think ontario is mid to low tier in terms of the US and Canada, and I was spoiled to grow up in the pacific northwest. As an aside, I think lots of people would agree with me, given that real estate prices in the pacific northwest are rising fast simply because so many people want to move there for good QOL.

One time deep in Yosemite, two days walk from any trailhead, we came upon a dude sitting on a log, he had mosquitos all over him and he wasn't moving. He lifted his head as we got close.
He ran out of food and was giving up.
We gave him bacon and chocolate right away, and some trail mix and oatmeal for later. He saw the bacon and gulped and started crying, it was awkward but we were concerned for him so we just ignored that part.
We made sure he wasn't going to just sit there and die, he bucked up and we got a laugh or two out of him.
Didn't hear any bad news later so I presume he made it out.

i was walking through the woods one cold late autumn day when I decided to go a bit off trail and follow an old and overgrown abandoned logging trail. By the looks of it barely anyone goes there, the grass was more than knee-high. I was enjoying the peace and tranquility of being alone next to some trees when i saw some dark dotty things moving in the distance. Now I'm an older fella and my eyesight ain't what it used to be so i was straining to make out what it was from a distance. Upon closer inspection, they seemed to be wild boars, very common here in chechia. My first instinct was to hide behind a tree and keep an eye on them, and in retrospect that seems like a stupid idea cause if they had noticed me i better had run away. Anyway i peeked around the side of the tree and they were minding their own business, doing pig stuff and i don't know if they see better than they hear or if their sense of smell is the most important one but whatever the case they didn't see me so i just turned back. At the time i only had a hiking stick with me so i would have been fucked if the alpha male started charging at me

I had a bobcat hiss at me and act like it was about to kick my ass once.
I was fishing and got to a spot where there was no bank on the creek, so I climbed up to some adjacent railroad tracks to walk around. A bobcat strutted out onto the tracks at about 30 yards away and stared at me. Her kittens bounced out of the bushes and onto the tracks behind her. I took some pictures of her and waited for them to clear off. After about 30 seconds, she took a few steps towards me and let out a nasty-sounding hiss. I started walking backwards away from her, deciding that no fish was worth getting my ass kicked by a bobcat.
I felt a bit like a pussy for letting a 20 pound animal bully me off the creek, but I imagine that fighting a bobcat would be like fighting a whirlwind of claws and teeth. I still can’t believe she wanted to fight rather than running away.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527147
the puget sound as a whole is okay, but the Seattle coastline is one of few parts they seem not to recommend (most likely due to urban pollution runoff in rainstorms), so yeah those guys would definitely be safer if they just cross the sound to bainbridge island

also for your gear, best thing to learn on is a medium or medium/light fishing rod and a spinning reel imho, both of which are more than abundant in Seattle thrift stores i imagine
medium/light will let you feel action from small panfish, while also holding up against medium-sized game like pike, bass, etc
12lb monofilament line is a good compromise in my opinion, light enough to work on most reels, while also tough enough to handle most medium-sized fish
for a line leader, it depends what fish you want (it can be 6-10lbs stronger than your line often), but if you're in a lake with pike, you're going to want a wire leader because those things will snap lines and steal lures like crazy

i hope your old man does well in surgery, I've made a lot of good memories fishing with my dad.

best spots are usually in rocky, slow & shallow swells of rivers, or on the rocky shores of lakes
while they thrive in warm waters, they also appreciate the shelter of rocks
if you shore fish, you can also just drop the bait trap near you as you fish for your other species, if you're there for a couple hours you can catch yourself a fair few

>why even go fishing?
there's still plenty of fish to consume safely, stuff like perch, bluegill, crappie, pumpkinseed, sunfish, etc that you can fish in bulk easily are both good for you, and the least likely to accumulate toxins
the Great Lakes are more polluted than most waterbodies around, so they dont cast a great picture of the whole of the recreational fishery
there's plenty of small lakes & ponds, and even whole rivers in the midwest/great lakes area that have very little or next-to-zero industrial pollution impacting their fisheries, its just that they're often tucked away, a few hours away from the nearest city, mine, paper mill, etc and you often have to get creative to access them

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529607
>Tenkara is really fun, it's just that one cane pole anon who takes it to the utter extreme and acts lie it's the end-all-be-all method to fish when it isn't.
You're experiencing a severe case of false memory, because I never stated nor implied any such thing. What I actually said is that I own and use almost every type of rod and pole imaginable, including cane poles; and that in some situations, a cane pole (or a literal stick) is the best tool for the job. In other situations, I'll use a fly rod, a tenkara rod, a spinning rod, a baitcaster, a microfishing rod, a catfishing rod, etc.

What I was responding to at the time was the assertion (perhaps yours, since you've chosen to perpetuate a false account of the conversation) that cane poles are for children or beginners, but are otherwise wholly inferior to spinning rods and baitcasters. From this I infer that you've only ever fished developed, maintained, popular waters, and have never been out in the backcountry casting in heavy brush, where every single one of your spinning rods and baitcasters would be instantly tangled. A cane pole is also best suited to dapping (a superior technique in tiny ponds and rivulets), regardless of surrounding cover. Tenkara and Western fly rods are actually terrible for dapping.

Since you're either clinically stupid or simply a liar, here is a long list of things that cane poles aren't good for:
>trolling
>ice fishing
>surf fishing
>catfishing
>offshore fishing
>fishing wide areas of large streams
>basically anything that requires distance, depth, and/or cranking something quickly

My beef as always is with people who think fishing is all about good-looking spinning and baitcasting rods (with color-coordinated line to match the finish, no doubt), really impressive casts, shiny clacking lures, and big bass dumped into an artificial lake with adjoining parking lot, when in reality this is a tiny sliver of the whole fishing experience. It's the pop music of the sport.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531285
>hung up on the bottom
Woah hey hold up, where are you fishing these where a glide bait hits the bottom? Unless I'm on a boat with a lure retriever, glide baits should be fished at the most mid water column, mostly they're fished upper water column even people on boats. Reason for this being, the sheer size of the lure has the drawing power to get fish from down deep and to utilize the top of the water as cover. Predator fish know that the top and the bottom are pinning zones, a bait fish can't swim further upwards if it's at the top nor deeper when it's already touching the bottom.

If you're primarily targeting fish on the bottom, switch to softbaits. You'll snag way less. If a river, a extra slow sinking glide, lo-float, or even a straight up floater would be better.

Most people on thru hikes don’t have time or the inclination to actually cook food at the end of a day of hiking. Food weight matters, as does fuel. There’s also the matter of time, though that’s minor. Shelf life and packability come into play as well.

Since you said it was a thru hike and specifically singled out freeze dried meals, I’m guessing you haven’t looked too much into what people are actually eating. They’re not eating ready made freeze dried stuff. Think of it this way: where do you generally resupply on a thru hike, and do those places sell free dried meals? Walmart is about the only exception, but generally you’ll be in a small town grocery store (or a gas station or Dollar General or something, depending on the trail and logistics).

Pic is true for thru hiking in the US. It’s mostly junk but that’s what people are bringing. The sodium content is fairly high, but you’re not eating this while sitting on the sofa. And f you’re on a popular trail every third or fourth day you’ll be in a town and can buy actual food.

>>2529759
I have the same issue. I'm based in Europe, but you should be able to get everything in a flyover land convenience store as well.

What you need is fibre. Oatmeal is pretty rich in fibre, lightweight, cheap and easy to prepare. I eat it once a day. Dried fruit like apples, figs or plums are also great. Don't get the half dried stuff because it tends to go bad. If you buy pasta, get whole wheat pasta (smaller size cooks faster, so less fuel). Granola bars work too but often they have too much sugar for me. And whenever you are in town, got some fresh vegetables, fruit, canned lentils, beans or chickpeas.

Minimize processed carbs like white bread, cookies, ramen, ect..

Happy shitting, anon.

>>2529916
No. In fact some grocery stores don’t even stock pepperoni in a refrigerated case, but just on a regular aisle. Same with various hard sausages and summer sausage. Of course they will eventually go bad after they’re opened, some faster than others, and all depending on ambient temperature.

Cheese is probably the worst. I bought extra sharp cheddar a few times on hikes where I had to resupply, and I could never finish the entire 8oz block before it started to look too funky (it gets soft, oily, and a little discolored). Maybe if I was going further in cooler weather it would have made sense, but it was always warm and only 4 or 5 days until resupplying.

I never had any issues with sausage or pepperoni, even on a 7 day stretch in Alabama. Pepperoni does get kind of brittle (compared to when it’s fresh), and it sweats a little, but I’ve never had it stink or get rancid or anything. Same with summer sausage, but I’m not a big fan. The artisanal sausages and salamis you can sometimes find in larger stores hold up well too, but they’re not widely available like the pleb tier stuff.

The basics are keep your bodyfat in a acceptable range (e.g. don't be fat. Seriously, hiking as a fat person is misery) and do occasional cardio (even talking walks every day is enough, just fucking move you lazy pig).
30 minutes of moderate walking (not even running or walking fast) a day is already something at least. Then get your heart pumping around 3 times a week (over 120 bpm average heartrate for a time of 30 minutes) and you are already "good". Add some lifting to that, especially functional lifts and stuff outside of machines (so you train more different muscle groups) and you are golden.

But most important is consistency, so find something that you can actually keep doing. Really enjoy riding the bike? Do that. Really enjoy swimming? Go swimming. Don't enjoy any sports? Combine them with something you do like. I ride my bike to my fishing spot or I walk to a coffee shop in the town over to have a cup of coffee. That way I have a reward and still do sports.
Otherwise a good low maintenance system is:
Daily walking around 30 minutes or other form of light activity (You should already do this). Can be combined with meditation or music/podcasts if your ADHD stricken mind can't handle the silence.
2-3 times a week gym visit, doesn't havae to be long, with lifting and a cardio session either before (for warmup) or after (if you somehow prefer that).
Combine with a halfway decent diet (don't be autistic, just eat a moderate amount of protein, try to eat whole healthy and preferably seasonal foods, cook for yourself/your family and keep an eye on caloric intake. Healthy fats if you can help it.)

Most important thing is to keep your ankles and knees happy, strong, and healthy and have full range of motion on every muscle from the hip downwards. You also need butt and core strength for good posture and to carry a heavy pack.

3-4x week cardio (rucking with 20 to 30lbs is less taxing on your knees than running, and also more practical)
3x week mobility (ankles & calfs, hamstrings, hip flexors & quads, outer hamstrings & glutes, inner hamstrings & groin)
3x week strength (tibialis, calf, hamstrings, glutes, abs, back, and forearms, wrists)

Ruck.
Hike with a heavyish pack. Go to hardware store, by bag of gravel (rocks about 1/4" to 1" in dia), sand bags used for floods. Put 10lbs of rocks in several bags. Put however many you want in your pack. Go /out/ for the day. Repeat, add weight as you get stronger. Builds core, hip and leg strength.

Run.
Get out and run once in a while.

Lift
Lift a few times a week.

Eat real food.

Started to backcountry elk hunt a few years back. Have iterated my way to this. I live at 1000 ft, and getting into shape using these things has helped me a lot. I have packed out a couple of elk in the last 4 years solo with 80 to 100 lb packs (quarter, with partial camp and gun). I can confidently hunt up to 6 miles and 3000 ft elevation change from the truck. 10000-11000 elevation.

In a week:
(3x) 1 mile/1.5km walks for these two 40 lbs kettlebells. Not allowed to put them down, so it's swapping between Farmer's Carry and Rack Carry on shoulders.
(3x) Jog three miles the next day.
(2x) 10 minutes of burpees and 10 minutes of kettlebell (30lb.) clean'n'press.
This adds up to ~2 1/2 hours of exercise a week and it's functional for moving through /out. A recent hike in difficult terrain and up steep hills was a complete joke. Back in the day I'd have been winded and struggling. This was one of the proud moments of my life, to so clearly feel vast improvement, both physically and mentally. Never figured I'd be one of those fit dudes who glides around trails but it was surprisingly easy to get here. Just 10-20 min of being tough each day.

Wildland Fire is one of the easiest ways to get your foot in the door, especially because in most cases your official job title is actually a "forestry technician/aid" and not "wildland firefighter" even though you spend plenty of time doing wildland firefighting.

>>2520747
Just keep them both dry over winter. Operculicarya decaryi is dry deciduous, so if you stop watering, it will/should lose all of its leaves until spring. First of all, though, I'd take both of them out of their pots and make sure the roots are still healthy. The yellowing leaves on the Dracaena don't sound good, but that could be because it's getting way too little, or way too much water. The soil looks dry in the picture, but it doesn't look like the pots have a drainage hole, so the soil at the bottom could still be pretty wet, especially if you're watering them rather frequently. I've found that the desert type Dracaena need really well-draining soil, as in pretty much just rocks and little to nothing else, to not die in cultivation.
Also, red leaves on an Operculicarya are normal if it gets a lot of UV light. Put it on your window sill and they'll turn green. O. decaryi will do fine in a peaty soil mix.

In short, I think there's nothing wrong with your O. decaryi, but the D. cinnabari could be in trouble. If you don't want to get addicted to alien desert plants, don't look up other plants that grow on Madagascar and Socotra respectively.

You can find more info on these plants and other succulents on Llifle. The layout is web 1.0 but the information there is very good.
http://www.llifle.com/Encyclopedia/SUCCULENTS/Family/Anacardiaceae/29905/Operculicarya_decaryi
http://www.llifle.com/Encyclopedia/TREES/Family/Dracaenaceae/32990/Dracaena_cinnabari

Another anon linked your post in /plant/ over on /an/, if you have any more questions about ornamental plants please post them there. I know it's pretty confusing that it's on a different board.

>>2517331
Can we turn this into a all around permaculture thread?

I'm essentially in the process of experimenting and finding a universal mix of ideal plant soil and ideal oak sawdust/innoculated substrate, wood chips, actual chunks or branches of oak, what layers in what order in what amounts - to consistently yield both fungi and vegetables in essentially any size plot, and is scalable. I want to be able to apply this recipe to everything from a small flower pot to a 20 acre farm field

I've gotten it to work indoors with pink oyster and garlic both successfully yielding in the same pot, the entire bottom half of the pot is basically mushroom food and drainage which will not need to be replaced for a very long time, and the top half is compost and soil

I want to apply this at scale with buried innoculated oak logs/branches/wood chips by the wheelbarrow full, and a top layer of universal soil and compost for just about any veggie i want. I'm not attempting to simulate a mycorrhizal network, we don't know how that shit works yet but I do want to create a sort of self-feeding system of as many edible species in 1 plot as possible. a sort of outdoor terrarium

main problem here is fungi do not play nice with eachother. you'd need 1 very successful strain of 1 mushroom, not 2 strains of the same species, and physical barriers between plots to keep species from outcompeting eachother.

I used a pickaxe to break the soil on my small backyard garden plots to dig them out about 1ft deep and then replace the soil with a 1/3rd clay (native soil), 1/3rd sand (from a local wash bed), and 1/3rd silt mix (from a local creek bank). If its small scale, you own a truck and a wheelbarrow and some garden tools, and you're fit enough or have help it only takes about a day to do 200-500 sq ft. Several years on and I can still push a stake about 1-2ft into the soil with almost no effort and tilling is easy, even during dry spells.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2527516
It's pretty hard to not get some kind of deficiency of one mineral or another.
Best bet might be wormtea. Get a nice wormcompost going, harvest compost and suspend it in a meshbag in a barrel of water with an airpump running bubbles through it. Add molasses or other sugars to boost microbial growth. Then filter of any solids and put that in your system. If you notice any signs of deficiency, you might be able to add an appropriate mineral at the brewing stage or directly into the wormbin. Not sure if it would work, but that's how I'd try it.
Aquaponics would be easier. Maybe you could install a fishtank in the garage?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527863
Yes. Chemical fertilizer is "hot" to seeds and microbes, so they need some time out adjust and broken down by letting the nature to do it's job. If your compost is good, a week's time is sufficient if you're in a hurry to plant the seeds catching the predicted time to harvest. Otherwise, few months of idle land while keeping the weeds out is perfect medium.

>>2529403
Just my [probably] bad take on it; saw dust is a byproduct of usable product. Using it to absorb spills or vomit is fine since it would be trash or firestarter anyway. For a food product like mushrooms, animal bedding, mulch, or other uses I'd be weary of its source. If Home Depot is giving it away thats fine but remember there are homeowners and contractors having just about any piece of wood cut. That includes treated lumber which has chemicals and arsenic in it. There may be manufactured wood that was cut like plywood or MDF which has water resistant glue in it. Not something I'd want in or near food crops/products.

For stuff that cannot have treated wood and glue or whatever else, Pine or cedar shavings are relatively cheap if it means knowing your chickens and mushrooms won't give you cancer. I'm seeing $10 for about 20lbs of it at retail, I'm sure you could find cheaper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2529427
If you're going to ask a home depot employee anything, its likely going to be a wrong answer. If you ask them if that saw is used to cut treated lumber or plywood I can already tell you the answer is yes. It cuts everything. Most of the time its for people who don't have a pickup truck to transport a 4x8 sheet of plywood or a 12 foot long plank of wood. They'll do a few courtesy cuts like that but they won't dice up something into a million small pieces so you don't have to.

Its a huge longshot but if you find a specialty woodworker near you like a cabinet maker, someone who does high end trim or some sort of expensive woodworker they'd be your best bet for getting sawdust that wasn't made using semi-dangerous wood (for your application). A tree cutting service would be decent too; they usually make a big pile of saw dust on the job site, then again when they're cutting it all up into fire wood to sell. Chat up someone selling a lot of firewood and see if you can go to their processing site and just scoop up saw dust.

I know the instagram trend is over but some people were using old shipping pallets to make furniture or flower beds. Pallets are always made with the cheapest possible wood but its often treated with something to resist weathering and falling apart since its often left outside for long periods of time and exposed to weather. Don't get free pallets and use the wood for anything other than shipping.

I have wine caps, Stropharia rugosoannulata, growing in woodchip mulch all over my yard right near a bunch of garden plants and shrubs. I've done nothing but spread mycelium along with the woodchip. Fungi can play nice together if they aren't competing for the same resources. Saprotrophic fungi usually specialize in decomposing either lignin or cellulose. You've probably herd the terms white rot and brown rot. So maybe you want to experiment with that.

posts.name: Anonymous

went and bought some finger lime, coffee arabica, and ice cream bean seedlings. whats the best way to take care of them ?

also, whats the best way to germinate seeds? Is there concensus on the best methods?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531659
>also, whats the best way to germinate seeds? Is there concensus on the best methods?
Depends on the species. Some seeds need certain temperatures for certain durations to split the seed coat. Some seeds you can file with a nail file or sandpaper. Some seeds you can give a warm water bath overnight. Some seeds need an acid bath. I like to just get a 10x20" spill tray fill it with 6 cells filled with potting-mix. I make little pits in each cell to the depth of whatever the seed needs. Sow the seeds. Then I either put them in the garage to get cold for the winter or under grow lights. I keep the soil moist by under-watering. I keep a fan nearby to keep airflow to keep seedlings from dampening off, get blasted by fungus, and to help strengthen them in general. If the particular type of seed needs to be really warm to germinate I put them somewhere that gets direct sunlight or I put them on a heating pad for a while. I keep them moist but let them get a little dry before rewatering and I just keep experimenting until I figure out a formula for each species.

Dracaena is a really common landscape plant here in south FL zone 10b. they like hot/humid summers with seasonal rain and dry winters.

that guy looks overwatered to me, but chlorosis could be from any number of things. if it were mine and I wanted to save it, I would repot it. not really a trick, but if it has sick slimey roots I cut off the rotted ones and pot it in straight new zealand sphagnum moss in a well draining container. it's the stuff orchids come in and you can find it in pet shops too because it's used in reptile terrariums. it is made of really long strands and holds just the right amount of water while giving the roots lots of air. it's great stuff.

>>2525125
This. Woodchip mulch will improve most types of soil you just have to be patient. I keep a heap that I let compost and I refresh smaller beds with it before the growing season. The stuff at the center of the pile goes on the beds and the bigger chips at the surface I put on pathways. Woodchip is nice because in wet weather it drains but it still holds moisture well. It makes sense where I live which is basically woodland with clay highly acidic dirt. Woodchip and leaf mold are how I build my soil. It really is as easy as chop it up, heap it up, wait, and spread.

>why are leather boots not a thing anymore?
they're not, most hiking boots have leather uppers.
if you mean full leather boots inside and out, its because everyone would rather hike on polyurethane and eva foam midsoles. they're more comfortable have no break in and are more waterproof.
the boots we make today are way better in every regard except the environmental impact. being able to re sole the same boot upper 4 or 5 times is a lot greener.
its a valid reason to want them, but on every other metric PU and EVA boots are just better.
>Tough and resilient material that can be maintained and repaired
it doesn't really matter how durable the upper of the boot is anymore because you can't really re sole foam midsole boots. they last long enough to do a thru hike in. very few people hike more than about 3000 miles at once.
rubber and foam make an amazing boot mid-sole, but they both have limited life spans from the repeated compressions they endure during their life.
full leather is what i would want in a work boot but not a hiking boot.
>Can be waterproofed (most nowadays come with a waterproof membrane)
a full leather boot can get pretty waterproof, but never as waterproof as something with a cemented or vulcanized mid.

posts.com:
Today's synthetic materials are designed to begin breaking down almost immediately. Modern boots are durable insofar as the materials used to create them are.

Leather, on the other hand, is a 'living' material. As long as it's cared for, it can survive for 20+ years.

So in summary, if you're content with buying new boots every couple years, go with modern. If you are more interested in a pair of boots that could last you 20+ years (as a bug-out or apocalyptic shoe kek) then go leather.

>>2518440
what kind of leather boot can be re-used? is there any tell? or can any leather boot be re-soled

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2519471
Generally, look for boots with thick leather insoles that also have leather welts and rubber or leather midsoles. These kinds can usually be taken apart, remade and reused for a very long time. If it is a glued sole, or a molded sole with foam, then you generally can’t have them for 20+years. Molded sole boots that are made of rubber like old stock US Panama Boots will last forever, and can be repaired. Go pick and choose what you need, and always consider costs. For example, if you got a pair of old German Bundeswehr boots with the PVC outsoles, you can simply have them repaired for less than $30 if you buy the soles and glue yourself. Old European military surplus are good choices, but try and get them quickly due to the money laundering operation in Ukraine.

You're conflicting two boots here, the Kampfstiefel 2000 (pic) and the Kampfstiefel 2007 (OP pic).
The Kampfstiefel 2000 are the ones with crumbling midsoles, but they can be resoled by any cobbler.
The Kampfstiefel 2007 fixed the crumbling midsole problem but can't be resoled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2522470
I have both. The ks2000 are welted on. I've had them resoled two times already. The ks2007 in OP crumble over time. You can even confirm this with Varusteleka reviews, or by even taking a look at the picture you posted vs OP's which has an irreplaceable sole.

The 2000s and earlier models are better for longevity. I do prefer the 2007 for comfort, but after two pairs in as many years I'm done buying them. There's no guarantee how long they've sat in storage before hitting the surplus store. I still have one pair hanging around of the 07 I could post an image of, but pictures are a dime a dozen on bushcraft forums.

Midsole hydrolysis impacts very new, i.e. mid to current 2000s boots, but not early German ks models.

Call me a bitch or whatever, i dont care.
Im a neverserved, never wore these in that context.
I got interested in the idea of not having to replace my boots every ~2 years and instead have them last longer or resole them if need be.
So i got a pair of Kampfstiefel 2000, as they are cheap and pleantiful here (Germany).
To preface this, i can normally hike comfortably 25-30km with a light to medium pack and if i push it go up to 35-40km.
I am completely trashed with these boots after ~15km, they are way too heavy.
I normally use loads of milsurp, because i am a poorfag (backpack, snivelgear, cooking equipment etc.), but this really doesnt seem to be worth it for me.
For a work application, where i dont walk that much, or use a vehicle i can see their value, beeing robust and waterproof.
>inb4 my legs are too weak
maybe,
but even then im preatty shure i could just walk further in modern hiking boots

Also their fit is rally fucking weird, they fit well in terms of lenght, but are way to high, allowing my heel to move up and down, never had this with any hiking boot before.
This is not supposed to be an argument against , milsurp/heavy gear, but an extra 0,5kg per boot really fucks my legs way more, than an extra 1kg on my pack ever would.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not the OP but I think I see what he's getting at and I have the same question. No one's denying that modern hiking boots are better, the question is how much worse leather really is.

I would be willing to compromise hiking quality somewhat for the self-reliance and longevity aspect of it. I love the idea of buying one pair of boots, and having them last for years and years of use and abuse doing maintenance and repair on them myself vs. spending several hundred bucks every year on the latest and greatest hiking boots. Especially with kind of a prepper mindset, that way you're no longer reliant on the world supply chain and shoe industry if the economy collapses or the bombs fall or whatever and you don't have access to that anymore.

So the real questions are:
>How much worse is hiking using leather boots (old-school ones, just stitched together leather and a rubber sole, no foam or synthetic materials included) vs. modern boots?
and
>How much maintenance can someone do without cobbler's tools and training? Could you easily learn from Youtube how to repair seams and even re-sole the boot yourself?

Im looking foward trying snow rackets, any tip I should know? are they useful or are they just for fun??
nice pics btw

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521592
I find them extremely useful. Much better than trying to stomp through snow for several miles. The pic I posted had snow ranging from heel height to above knee height which will drain you quickly without any snowshoes/skis. Skis are also nice obviously, but I find snowshoes to be easier to deal with in this terrain. The ones I have are 30" snowshoes, metal frame and deep spikes, rated at a weight up to about 125kg/275lbs ish depending on snow conditions. Most people will do fine with a 25", but thats up to your total weigth. Obviously it's a bit weird to use if you've never used snowshoes before, as you may have to get used to a slightly wider walking stance depending on the snowshoes, but I've used much wider ones before that I've ran in, so these slimmer ones were a luxury to me.
I'd recommend making sure you get the right weight rating; you + your pack + other stuff youre carrying. Heel lift is also a plus if you think you'll need it. And personally I prefer slim and long, vs short and wide. Of course make sure theyll fit you nicely, this isnt usually an issue for most people as theyll usually adjust to most feet(EU38-47). Just make sure to double check. I'm not deep into brand research, but Tubbs is something I see consistently come up as a good manufacture, so its a starting point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A map case? Christ, the LARPing is completely out of control on this board. Order/print out your topo map (note: you need to know what you're doing a bit to preserve scale when printing it yourself), section it with an Xacto knife, laminate the sections with matte lamination pouches (can be done with a clothing iron and cover sheet, don't need a laminator), trim the excess, then use a rubber band or two to make a bundle of your map leaves. Presto, waterproof map you can draw on with a grease pencil or erasable/permanent marker. A base plate compass and maybe a scale/ruler protractor such as picrel are the only other things you'll need. All of this will snap into the rubber band bundle.

You strike me as the kind of dipshit who decides he's going to acquire something, gets really excited, and then consooms every conceivable accessory to go along with it. You do you, but over 90% of /out/ relies entirely on their phone GPS; the few of us who can navigate don't buy pretentious mapping accessories. It's the navigation equivalent of buying goggles, a cashmere scarf, and lambskin driving gloves to go with your new car.

>>2521038
Weight is basically a wash compared to a double walled tent. An underquilt isn’t much more bulky than a comfy inflatable, a tarp and hammock are about the same size as a tent and ground sheet, and a top quilt is literally a quilt. It is slightly heavier, but that depends on temperature. In the South during the warmer months I don’t need a top or under quilt while a tent is basically impossible to use because it’s so damn hot (and even if you do you’ll still need a pad).
>you need trees
That’s not a problem for the eastern half of the US, including the South. It’s sort of a given that you wouldn’t take a hammock if it were questionable, but in those areas there’s no question; you can find trees in a forest.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2521045
This pic is my setup, which is similar to OP’s. It’s actually quite simple.

Once you’ve set it up a few times, you learn how high the ends of the hammock should be so the bottom of the hammock will be the appropriate height off the ground (so you can sit with your feet flat, like a chair). Parts of my suspension are different colors, so when I set it up the bug net zipper will be on the appropriate side.

You also learn how high each end has to be, and where the tarp has to sit so it’s evenly spaced. You’d think there would be a lot of fiddling to get these things right, but not really.

I don’t even bother taking my tarp out of the skins until bed time (unless it’s raining). I just hang it over the hammock until it’s needed. Sometimes I leave it off just to look at the stars. Same with my under quilt. It doesn’t get put in place until it’s bedtime, unless it’s cold enough while I’m eating (I eat in my hammock because why not?).

So complications of setup aren’t really a thing once you’ve used it a few times, and setup time isn’t really a thing, since it’s not set up from start to finish in a single process.

On thing that really improved my hammock experience (and ground if I'm just tarp camping) was a tarp snake and setting up the fly to use zero knots. The tarp has linelocs and addition of a couple carabiners and prusik knots makes it simple as hell to get up and down.

Hammocks are different but may not be better or worse. Hammocks and tarp campers are cut from the same cloth so to speak, the thing that people get hung up on is that there's many ways of doing everything and people constantly fiddle with their set ups. A big advantage of a tent when starting out is that it only goes up one way. When you're just starting out it might not be the worst idea simply because at the end of the day you can just select a site and do things the same way each time. A hammock or tarp's flexibility is also a challenge as you get kind of option overloaded. If you're still a beginner it may be better to just go with a decent tent and get dialed in on all the other things insofar as gear and planning, then complicate the shelter arrangement. The good news is if you buy any decent tent it's still good kit if and when you go hammock.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2527546
The following is a sort of bare-bones minimum, but honestly you don’t need more.

>the hammock
Gathered end with a zipper-attached bug net is pretty standard. Bridge style is expensive and rare, also heavy, but super comfortable. Spreader bar is a meme.

The hammock should be 11’ from end to end. 10’ might work if you’re a woman or the height of a woman. ENO and most Amazon hammocks are too short for most actual men.

Make a structural ridge line. It’s a rope with two permanent loops on either end. Make it 83% the length of your hammock (about 110” if you have an 11’ hammock). This ensures that you’re always hanging at 30° no matter what your suspension is doing. They’re pretty cheap if you want to just buy one, but it’s super easy to make.

Hang the foot end higher than the head end. This will prevent you from having the sensation that you’re constantly sliding down whenever you readjust. Play around with it; I like mine about a foot higher.

Lie on an angle. This will cause you to be nearly flat in a hammock hung with a fair amount of sag (which it will have due to the ridge line).

>suspension
Whoopie slings are ok. They save a little weight and a little bulk. You have to pair them with tree straps anyway.

Long straps (generally 1” wide, 12’ or 15’ long, polyester, NOT NYLON) with some kind of hardware (such as cinch buckles) are a little easier because there’s a single adjustment and no knots. Straps with multiple loops are ok, but the advantage over plain straps with hardware isn’t that big considering they’re twice as heavy and bulky.

>underquilt
You can try a pad, but it’s just not as comfortable. They move around and don’t bend easily. Get an underquilt or make a “no sew PLUQ” for maybe $60 months f you’re poor (Google it; it’s good down to maybe 45°).

>tarp
Hex shape, catenary cut, 11’ from end to end. Doors and beaks are nice but not needed. Zing-It makes an excellent guy line rope.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: There's a couple things you want to watch out for. Protein is the obvious one but there's others. Dietary B12 only comes from meat but you can easily supplement with vitamins. Iron from plants is less bioavailable but can also be supplemented. Other than that, the usual trail mix of seeds and nuts is really helpful for getting enough protein and essential fatty acids. The big divide in this category is Omega 6 vs Omega 3 fatty acids. Most give O6 (peanuts, sunflower seeds, hazlenuts, etc), while only a few give O3 (ground flax seeds, hemp hearts, chia seeds). For me a tablespoon or so of hemp for O3 plus a good assortment of the O6 varieties seems to do the trick. Another thing to keep in mind is that a lot have people have decided that grains = bad, but as a veggie you'll likely get most of your calories, protein, and water soluble vitamins from them. So choose ones with more concentrated nutrients and eat a variety of them (wheat is king, oats and potatoes are good, rice is poverty tier). One last tip, it's really easy to go overboard on vegetables that are heavy in oil-soluble vitamins, like carrots and spinach, because they tend to be cheap and versatile. The problem is that oil-soluble nutrients build up in your system and can become toxic at high enough levels. So don't just eat a ton of carrots for your vegetables, moderation is key. If you have any questions about what's the best bang for the buck, I highly recommend the site https://nutritiondata.self.com/. It pulls the data from the Standard Reference USDA nutrition database, which is by far the most complete, detailed, and well-sourced nutrition reference I've ever found.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Another thing I forgot to mention: there are three Omega 3 fatty acids: ALA, EPA, and DHA. The most important (essential) is the one I mentioned that comes from seeds (ALA). But the two others only come from fish, although they're less important (conditionally essential) but still great to add to your diet. For a vegetarian, the only realistic source of this is krill-based Omega 3 supplements. These often also include the seed based ALA as well, so you don't have to worry about taking flax or hemp hearts with you. So consider taking a krill O3 supplement.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I am out innawoods and want to build a fire I will start with very small diameter twigs. The dead ends of pine tree branches, for example, that are about the diameter of a pencil led. I will add twigs of increasing size, the diameter of a pencil , for example, and increase the amount of wood and size of the branches until I have the fire I want.
I say all of this because I have built hundreds of fires in all conditions over the years. I have a nice wood fire going in my Fisher Papa Bear wood stove right now. I am currently burning a mix of seasoned red oak and white oak I harvested about 3 years ago.
Anyway, I do not have anything against batoning but I rarely do it. Just never need to. Is it because I live in Appalachia and fire wood is so plentiful ? so I never have to baton to build a fire ?
In these knife threads someone always brings up batoning like it is some critical knife performance measure. Which is fine, but it puzzles me since I never need to do it. It would be a waste of time and energy for me to baton because the size wood I need is always available.
Anyway, it is 5 degrees F outside, snow is covering the yard, I have a nice fire going in my wood stove. The power and all utilities are on. I have a nice cup of coffee and the sun is about to come up this morning. I am truly blessed here in my Appalachian refuge and wish the best for all of you all wherever you may be.

Nessmuk, aka George Washington Sears, really did write the book on camping and woodcraft back in the late 1800s.
Here’s the public domain PDF of the book:
https://www.gutenberg.org/files/34607/34607-h/34607-h.htm

Nessmuk strongly advocated for traveling light, but he also advocated using what became known as the “Nessmuk Trio”-a double bit hatchet (one end thin for cutting clean wood, the other left fat for heavier duty work, a fixed blade knife, and a folding knife to handle basically any cutting task outdoors.

Something important to consider with this is that blades (decent ones anyway) are designed with a purpose. There are going to be design choices in terms of handle, blade shape, steel, and edge that make them better for certain tasks. The majority of knife makers big and small are not going designing for a niche task role. Some will, but decisions that make it a better splitting tool will make it a less effective knife.

Over all knife batoning is juice that's not worth the squeeze. Can it be done? Sure. Do I see a lot of opportunities where wood needs to be processed but I also can't carry a superior tool for the job? No, not really.

The only "wore out" knives you have ever seen are the product of some retard beating it through a log with a rock or some fudd "sharpening" his knife 2 times a day with an angle grinder. Once you have a good edge on your knife, 99% of the time all you need is a ceramic hone and leather strop to maintain it. The only time I even use my diamond plates anymore is remove chips/damage, re-profile, or to bring back an edge someone else has neglected for a very, very long time. >>2528692
Sorry you bought a meme. It’s not tall enough to sit up, the ventilation is subpar, and it’s a front entrance design. >>2528782
There’s no such thing as a four season tents. There are tents that can handle heavy snow loads and high winds and tents that can’t. The former are usually quite heavy, often expensive, and generally have pretty terrible ventilation while the later are much lighter, much more common, and the good ones are designed to breath well. Using a winter tent in the summer isn’t a good idea, mostly because of the ventilation/condensation issue.

It’s pretty well accepted that the Durston X-Mid is probably the best non-freestanding tent out there right now. The SMD Lunar and Gossamer Gear One are pretty standard non-freestanding designs that are decent as well.

The MSR Hubba is one of the more popular free standing tents but I think it’s over priced. The Big Agnes Copper Spur and REI Half Dome are popular as well. Two people in my old hiking group had Copper Spurs and they really are well built, but again, they’re pretty pricey.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530578
socks last 6-12 months at most.
the best you're gonna do is something like darn toughs where they have a lifetime replacement policy.
>does material matter or can i get a couple packs from walmart?
yes it matters a lot.
merino wool is not durable make sure its blended with nylon if you want it to last. long term merino gets this crusty glossy texture even if there's no holes in the socks.
bison down socks are more durable than merino wool but expensive. long term it suffers from pilling.
cheap polyester athletic socks from walmart will last the longest by far, and also be the cheapest.
polyester is better in hot weather, wool & various exotic natural fibers are better in cold weather. polyester gets stinky but dries out fast. the other ones resist smell. choose according to your climate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2530602
>>2530754
They don’t technically replace them. They give you a voucher for the amount equal to the ones that are being replaced. So if you send them a pair that would cost $13 to replace, you get a $13 voucher. If you get the same model, you break even.
>but y tho?
Probably because they’re hoping you’ll spend more. You’ll already be on their website, and already paying a few dollars for shipping (it’s not included in the warranty), so you might as well buy more.

I’ve swapped socks three times with them. The first time was a pair of used for a 300+ mile thru hike. They were just worn out; no jokes or anything, just thinner than new. The second time was a really old pair that I think I stretched out by leaving them folded over themselves and in the bottom of a plastic tote and forgotten about. The third time was from a puppy that found them, which they say isn’t covered yet here we are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Project zomboid
I appreciate the in-depth and very broad scope of the game, you can really do anything. I found that a bit intimidating though, having to read about how the mechanics work gets annoying, and the isomorphic view isn't my cup of tea.
>Sea of thieves
I love pirates and the game's aesthetic but it gets kind of boring pretty quickly, you can spend hours doing deliveries and make some money but... Nothing. I feel the game needs a main story with a definitive goal.
>Minecraft
I feel it fits the /out/ theme well enough, I never bothered with mods but there are mods for temperature effects and whatnot. Someone also suggested vintage story, a minecraft clone with a focus on realistic survival; food rots, crops affected by temperature, stone knapping... Wow, I'm gonna need to look into that one.
>Skyrim
Hardcore RPG players hate how they made the mechanics a bit more simple but that's why I like it. It looks great and the fantasy world is comfy AF, there are also survival mods for it but I never tried any.
>Breath of the wild
If you own a switch you own this game and anyone who has played it knows how /out/ it is.
>Arctico
Still in development futuristic arctic sci-fi survival/adventure game. I got it for $1 and played about 5 hours in total. It's nice but I haven't gotten very far so I can't say much about it. There is some kind of story involving discovering abandoned bases but I don't know apart from that. There's fishing and caves. Boring, but it's being developed regularly.

I'll have to check out some of the suggestions in this thread and put a sale notification on them. Game responsibly though, they're so easy to get carried away with. No matter how /out/ the game is you're still inside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here are my thoughts on some games.

>Minecraft
Base game has low content, but modding community is the best in the world. If you spend some time customizing the experience, you get the game tailored for you. 8.5/10

>The Forest
Surviving is very basic. Construction is not very complex and enemy AI is bad. Good fun for the first 20 hours, but then it gets pretty stale as a survival game and turns into a monster fighting RPG. 6/10

>Project Zomboid
Artstyle and UI is very oldschool, but there is a deep and rich gameplay. On singleplayer, after you build your base the game basically ends. The fun is in multiplayer, but then it becomes a sort of grindy base battle royale(Rust/DayZ). Great game for urban survival. 9/10

>Green Hell
Probably the best survival game, but has a small non-procedural map(About 30hrs of gameplay). 9.5/10

>7 days to die
Another deep and rich gameplay, but the some skills makes it feels more "gamey" than a real survival. Blood moon hordes and radioactive zombies are too much fantasy for me. 8/10

>Rain World
Not a human survival game, but a very good one. The wild monsters give insane fear goosebumps, and it actually feels like a real survival experience. 9.5/10

>Valheim
Way more of a Crafting RPG than a survival. Modded Minecraft is better. 7.5/10

>The Long Dark
I refunded this game. Game feels extremely linear due to story mode and gameplay just feels unnecessary punishing, intead of just difficult. 2/10

>This War of Mine
Good game, but only played 3 times since base gameplay is not very replayable. DLCs are decent, but they are story driven instead of gameplay driven. 7.5/10

>Dont Starve Together
Insane way of interpretating seasons. You start in summer collecting resources, prepared things during autumn, try to survive the cold winter with low food, then you have wet rainy spring. Then it is summer again, but this time with harsh desert-like sun and new wild creatures. Solid survival, but then it turns into an exploration RPG. 9/10

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here I will post outdoors pictures I took from my life in France and comment on them

A limestone quarry in Creil, northern France. Probably from the 18-19th century. Old newspapers from the 90's were thrown away there

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Forêt de chantilly in northern France, around the castle of Chantilly, not far from Paris
Many ticks in the foilage, as deer inhabit these woods and are still hunted with hunting dogs the old fashioned way

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
La sèvre Nantaise river in Northwestern France. Its a slightly deep valley surrounded by wineyards and pastures. Muscadet wine is produced there.
Its an oceanic climate which can only be found in western europe and New zealand, although NZ is noticeably warmer and UK is is colder

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: La Somme region in northern France, named After the river Somme which has been turned into a canal. Today people bike alongside it and can visit WW1 memorials in this very rural region.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A forest of spruce trees in the Jura region, a mountaineous region in eastern France.
The main mountain ranges in France are all located in the east and are as follow, from north to south : Ardennes (shared with belgium), Vosges (part of the same forest as the black forest in Germany), Jura, Savoie, Haute-Savoie, Écrins, Vanoise, Mercantour
The highest mountains of France are in haute Savoie so the Jura is relatively low in altitude, summits mostly reaching 2000m altitude at most

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Jura still

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mercantour mountain range, the closest to the mediteranean sea, thus it has med influences. The summits are round and dry and the grass is all burnt up during summer. Its also the only place in France where you can find larches.
The first sightings of the return of the wolf in France in the 90's were made there
Pastoralism is still a strong tradition in this wild area

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: More of Mercantour

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Around Nice, on the coast of the mediteranean sea, altitude is lower so it is much warmer
Many streams flow down the hills into glens, where the shadow and humidity allow for different plants to grow into a little jungle

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: These glens can get flooded during heavy rains. You can also find dead animals, and wrecks of cars, and many other strange items. Spiders like to place their webs above the streams

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Back to Mercantour. It is so wild, hikkers regularly disappear, and they are never found out again.
Carrion birds can take care of carcasses really fast. Better not venture out from the tracks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Cows and wolves have to share the same forests

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In mediteranean France, you cant hide from the sun. During summer, it can get to 35 degrees celsius pretty quick.
It smells of olive trees, pine needles, and you can hear the cicadas

There used to be many water mills, but now theyre all ruins

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Compiègne forest in northern France. There arent many "wild" forest in France anymore : since antiquity, they have been reworked into optimal wood production and circulation for the royal hunts
Even then, theyre nice to walk around.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Alabaster Coast is in Normandy. Tall cliffs of white chalk dominate the sea. Not far from D-day sand beaches. Normandy is also know for its apples, cider and dairy products (camembert, cream, milk)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Chalk and limestone is everywhere in northern France

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: A forest in the Ardennes. French Ardennes are not "wild" per se since they have been used for woods, but theyre quite desertic. You can go for days without seeing anybody. Just praise you dont get shot by a drunk hunter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: La sèvre Nantaise river again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: In the 50's, the water was safe for safe for consumption and swimming, but chemicals products used in the agricultural corps above the valley have made it unsafe

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Back in northern France, where everything is flat and nature is heavily domesticated. Potato and beet fields everywhere, and the rivers are turned into canals for the boats to reach Paris and Belgium.
This is where I walked 60km for the first time since its all flat

And thats it for today, have a good read anons

>>2528058
Looks like the southeastern alps ?

Pyrénées is the southwestern mountain range, its very wild and has bears, on the borders of spain. Pilgrims cross that mountain range to reach saint jacques de Compostelle.

In Northwestern France you have Britanny which has celtic heritage, climate akin to UK, cliffs above the ocean, islands, and rivers flowing deep into valleys in the countryside, such as scorff river (picrel) or léguer river. Outside of summer you wont meet many people except fishermen.

The countryside of Nantes also has the Maine river and Sèvre Nantaise river end Erdre river and Loire river which are beautiful.

Emphasis on rivers because Northwestern France is flat so theres a lot of agricultural fields and few forests

Pros
>extremely warm
>insulation can't get wet
>waterproof

Cons
>bulky/heavy and somewhat stiff
>have to wear very long socks or the rubber will cut into your calves
>sweaty feet (won't make the boots less warm but kinda gross)
>can be hard to find an unissued pair in the right size

posts.sub: Fossil General #1? First Shark Tooth addition
posts.com:
The purpose of this general is to encourage people to go /out/ and find cool fossils. This trad is also a place to share our own collections and things we find when we are /out/ fossil hunting.

I hope everyone here will enjoy this thread and hopefully this can be a regular thread on this board.
Rules are,
>To just post ad discuss fossils and other related geological subjects.
>When you post about a fossil in your collection, please label it with what formation it is form, what is it, and where in the world it is form.
>If you don't know where it originated or the species that is ok, just label it as so
Pic related is and Uknown spices of shark tooth, Eagle Ford formation, Denton Co. Texas
Pic also related is my first shark tooth I have found within the Eagle Ford formation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2526451
Coal strip-mines a definitely a place to look, if you have any creeks dry or wet, those are a good spot to look. I'm not Familiar with the Northeast but it wouldn't be a bad idea to look up a geological map of the area you are in and look for locale Fossil hunting groups to get a better idea of the fossil deposits that you are near.
http://northtexasfossils.com/geologycollin.htm
here is a link to the Collin Co. geologic map that I use when looking for places to go fossil hunting. This map isn't perfect as there are areas that I know of that are apart of the Eagle Ford shale that aren't on the map as well as some creeks that aren't on there as well so it's always good to cross reference with a satellite map like Apple maps if you have an iPhone
I hope this helps anon.

>>2528037
Dinosaur anon here, everything in the collection I posted is surface collected, as digging is illegal where I am. It's not even necessary though, and teeth are probably easier to find on the surface anyway, you just need to do a lot of walking. For artifacts, it's a different story. The people who have boatloads of points tend to be diggers who tear apart sites and collect everything.

Just wrought-up a new Op post
Looks like this

The purpose of this general is to encourage people to go /out/ and find cool fossils and artifacts. This thread is also a place to share our own collections and things we find when we are /out/ hunting.

Rules are as follows,
>To just post and discuss fossils and other related geological subjects.
>When you post about a fossil in your collection, please label it with what formation it is from, what it is, and where in the world it is from.
>If you don't know where it originated or the species that is ok, just label it as so
Helpful Links
https://paleobiodb.org/navigator/
https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/
https://zoom.earth/
Geologic maps of US states (usgs.gov)
A Beginner's Guide To Fossil Hunting - Fossil Hunting Trips - The Fossil Forum

If anyone has anything else, I should add let me know by tomorrow so I can start a new thread around Sunday.

Best way to find fossils is to be motivated. Go to a museum and see what kinda stuff your area has.
